It can be pruned to branch. We have also found it to be a particularly hardy cultivar, tolerating outside exposure lower than other Aeoniums.

Name: Echeveria nuda
Short description:
Echeveria nuda var. montana is a branch forming species from Mexico.
 \n
 \nThis tall growing Echeveria can grow up to 30cm in ideal conditions, making it one of the tallest growing of its kind. The stems are thin and will carry the main rosette before offsetting multiple times, the leaves are a bright green and will blush red under strong light. This species will bloom in summer, throwing off dark purple spikes that carry the most attractive vertical yellow flower display.
 \n
 \nPerfect for adding height to any succulent planter.

The underside of the leaves covered in hundreds of cells that look just like crystals. It flowers strongly several times a year with multiple stems of striking orange flowers.

Name: Aloe polyphylla (Spiral Aloe)
Short description:
All of the Aloes available have been carefully grown from seed and are now growing in a pot measuring 13cm in width. We send the Aloe bare-root, without its pot.
 \n
 \nThey are incredibly different Aloes due to their unique leaf formation which corkscrews out from the center of the plant.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nSpiral Aloe's natural home is of the Maluti Mountains of Lesotho in South Africa. These Aloes can withstand freezing temperatures (-15��C) they can often be under snow in their natural habitat.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nThey make a fantastic garden showpiece that can be grown vertically in a rock wall or planter.
 \n
 \nFor best results when planting, slightly angle the plant to ensure rainwater runs freely from the crown.
 \n
 \nIt will appreciate feeding throughout the growing season, ensure a free draining soil mix but maintain water as they can be a thirsty plant.
 \n
 \nThey are an extremely fast growing Aloe, perfect UK hardy succulent.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nPlant in a south facing aspect and enjoy this beautiful work of nature.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nYou will receive a plant similar in size to pictures 2 and 3 (approx. 10-15cm diameter), the other images are of mature specimens several years old. We send out our Aloes bare root without pot, as they travel far better in the post.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nView our Care Guide for more information on how to look after your Aloe polyphylla.

Echeveria mucronata is a species roumered to have been found in mountainous regions of Hidalgo, Mexico.

 \n
 \nA plant suitable in a standalone pot or planted indoors with other house plants.

Short description: Agave parryi 'Cream Spike' is an attractive and compact variegate that grows to a manageable size of about 15cm diameter.� Readily offsets babies from the base as it matures which can be planted separately or left in place to create a stunning multi headed display. \n \nThe plant you receive was grown in a 1 litre pot, bigger than most our succulents.

Echeveria amoena is a clump-forming species with attractive grey-green leaves.

 \n
 \nPerfect for adding to your indoor succulent collection as a standalone specimen or with others.

Name: Aeonium canariense var. palmense
Short description: Aeonium canariense var. palmense is rare in cultivation. It is endemic to La Palma and grows on shady, moist slopes meaning that it is suitable for wetter, shady spots in the garden, although it also performs well in full sun. Rosettes are bowl-shaped up to 40cm diameter. Seed grown.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium ciliatum
Short description: Aeonium ciliatum is a species found on the island of Tenerife, in strong sunlight the plant will develop a red tinge on the outer margins of its leaves.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium davidbramwellii
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium diplocycla v. gigantea
Short description: Aeonium diplocycla var. gigantea is not often found in cultivation as it was only discovered in La Gomera Canaries in 2001 by B. Malkmus. As you can see by the picture it has a very compact, stemless growing form which can get to a very big size. The central rosettes tend to close over when the weather warms up.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium domesticum
Short description: Aeonium domesticum is one of the most striking in the collection with its variegated leaves and clump-forming rosettes.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium glutinosum
Short description: Aeonium glutinosum is a species from Madeira. This plant has a natural sticky substance on the leaves and stem. In good light the leaves can produce a red tinge which is very attractive.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium goochiae
Short description: On offer is this Aeonium goochiae, a species that is found on the island of La Palma. It is not like most Aeoniums as its leaf shape is very different from other species. It is found growing in cliff faces and rocky outcrops in the northern parts of the island.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium arboreum v. holochrysum
Short description: Aeonium arboreum var. holochrysum are common in there natural habitat in the Canary Islands but not often found in cultivation. It is branching and can grow to a good size (1 metre+) and in strong sunlight, the leaves can turn a reddish-brown colour.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium lancerrotense
Short description:
Aeonium lancerrotense is a clump-forming Aeonium species from Lanzarote.
 \n
 \nThey are mostly found growing 400m above sea level, and when fully grown, they should produce a large number of pink flower heads.
 \n
 \nPerfect in a standalone pot.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium longithyrsum
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium arboreum v. magnificum
Short description: Aeonium arboreum var. magnificum is an attractive lime-green variety. With it's large leaves and flat rosettes it tends to offset often. Once mature it has a fantastic bright-yellow flower head.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium manriquiorum
Short description:
Aeonium manriqueorum is native to Gran Canaria. This is a branching species that can grow to around a metre diameter and height.
 \n
 \nIts leaves will take in pink-red tints in strong light/dry conditions. It also has a pleasant balsam fragrance. The flowers are yellow bulb-like shaped.
 \n
 \nWould be perfect as a standalone feature plant.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium 'Marnier Lapostolle'
Short description: This Aeonium was found in southern France. As you can see in the picture it has stunning striations on the leaves and if grown in good light the pinkish colour in the leaves will be highlighted even more. Synonymous with Aeonium 'Blush'.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium percarneum
Short description:
Aeonium percarneum is one of the rare Aeonium species that has flowers with a pink/red tinge.
 \n
 \nIt is a low, branching species that can reach 1 metre in height but is usually smaller. The foliage takes on an attractive pink/red tint in high light levels.
 \n
 \nIt is a native of Gran Canaria where it has a wide distribution, making it adaptable in garden cultivation. It can also be grown successfully in a pot.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium pseudourbicum
Short description:
Aeonium pseudourbicum is a species that grows as a single monocarpic stem. It also features red outer-leaf margins under strong light.
 \n
 \nThey can grow up to 1m high and make a fantastic specimen plant.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium puntallanense
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium saundersii

Name: Aeonium smithii

Name: Aeonium goochiae 'Ballerina'

 \n

Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aloe microstigma
Short description:
This attractive seed grown Aloe species from southern Africa is one of the most free-flowering species. They can grow to 60cm in height. The leaves are blue-green with conspicuous white markings and can take on a red tinge in dry conditions. The flower spikes are up to 1 metre high during the summer with orange / red flowers.
 \n
 \nThey make a perfect succulent for a conservatory as they have been known to flower up to 3 times in one season.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria stolonifera

Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria mexicensis
Short description:
Echeveria mexicensis is a species native to Mexico, it can be found growing in the pine forests.
 \n
 \nIt features beautiful powdery, blue leaves with pink markings on the leaf tips. The flower spikes are large and come in numbers, they contain large bell-shaped flowers with hints of yellow and orange.
 \n
 \nA lovely, white succulent. You can always distinguish this one from your other ones due to it's smaller size and unusually perfect rosette. It would look fantastic planted indoors with other succulents in an arrangement, or terrarium.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Phoenix Flame'
Short description:
Amazingly, Aeonium 'Phoenix Flame' is a tried and tested winter survivor. It survived temperatures as low as -6�C.
 \n
 \nAeonium 'Phoenix Flame' is one of our own outstanding hybrids. This plant holds a perfect clumping form that produces multiple rose shaped rosettes. It looks absolutely stunning in the summer.
 \n
 \nAnother great feature of this succulent is the fact that it can grow in cooler conditions, it particularly likes autumn and spring.
 \n
 \nIt is a very compact plant that holds fantastic form and colour. It will also offset incredibly quickly.
 \n
 \nAeonium 'Phoenix Flame' is a cross between Aeonium 'Firecracker' x Aeonium dodrentalis.
 \n
 \nIt makes an ideal container succulent as it won't become too dominant if planted with other succulents.
Tags: Beginner, Indoors, Rare & Unusual, Surreal Hybrid
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Emerald Flame'
Short description:
Aeonium 'Emerald Flame' is a cross between Aeonium 'Firecracker' x Aeonium dodrentalis. It keeps a low clumping form, it offsets slightly slower than A. 'Phoenix Flame' and doesn't have the same deep red colouration in the leaves but in the summer it takes on its own characteristics with flecks and striations coming out on the older leaves.
 \n
 \nThis plant was named by Kesher Ashby, our competition winner on facebook, thank you Kesher.
 \n
 \nAmazingly, this Aeonium has survived outside in temperatures as low as -6?.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Ice Warrior'
Short description: Aeonium 'Ice Warrior' was bred for it's hardiness, hence the name. Whilst not invincible against freezing temperatures it will put up a brave fight to make it through. The parent plants are Aeonium smithii x Aeonium 'Cyclops' both of which can withstand temperatures below freezing. The underside to the leaves show distinct characteristics of Aeonium smithii, you will see these markings consistently in the hardier varieties of Aeonium.
Tags: Beginner, Indoors, Rare & Unusual, Surreal Hybrid
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria agavoides 'Ebony'
Short description:
Echeveria agavoides 'Ebony' was originally�found growing in Mexico by John Trager and Myron Kimnach, it was released in cultivation�in the year 2000.
 \n
 \nIt quickly became one of the most sought-after Echeveria's around and became incredibly popular in Asia, with the price for just one plant costing well over �300.
 \n
 \nThey are notoriously slow to offset but easily one of the most beautiful and rewarding Echeveria's around, the most attractive feature has to be their pale green-grey leaves set off by their almost black outer leaf margins.
 \n
 \nThey are stunningly beautiful and structural succulents that rarely encounter any problems with pests or diseases.
 \n
 \nThey make fantastic houseplants as they are so robust and easy to care for, just place them in a bright/sunny windowsill and water when the soil dries, feed with a slow-release feed in the spring. They love our summers so growing them outdoors in a pot or in the garden in full sun will show off their full potential an intensify the dark outer leaf margins.
 \n
 \nIf kept�dry outside during the winter they are hardy down to -7.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \n
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Echeveria 'Bella' is a fantastic hybrid of unknown parentage.
 \n
 \nThis plant is a great example of a spreading succulent as it will stay quite small but throw offsets off regularly to fill a space. The leaves are slender, long and range from dusky brown to green, it features a lot of leaves that create a very strong and structural rosette. Echeveria 'Bella' will flower in the spring.
 \n

Name: Jovibarba allionii
Short description:
A beautiful species with neat, small bright green rosettes.
 \n
 \nJovibarba are a close family member of Sempervivum, the differences are that they produce their pups from the stems or amongst the leaves and will a lot of the time, roll away from the mother. Whereas the Sempervivum will always offset using stolons. They also have bell-shaped flowers rather than the Sempervivum star-shaped flowers.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Jovibarba heuffelii 'Aquarius'
Short description:
A Jovibarba hybrid created here in the UK by Ernie Fearnley in 1972.
 \n
 \nLike the rest of the heuffelli varieties, it offsets within itself to create an original feature in your succulent display. This beautiful plant is extremely resilient and features green leaves with burgundy tips under strong light.
 \n
 \nBest planted outdoors all year round but protected from hail to avoid physical damage to the plant. Looks great with an array of other Sempervivum.
 \n
 \nJovibarba are a close family member of Sempervivum, the differences are that they produce their pups from the stems or amongst the leaves and will a lot of the time, roll away from the mother. Whereas the Sempervivum will always offset using stolons. They also have bell-shaped flowers rather than the Sempervivum star-shaped flowers.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Parva'
Short description: Echeveria 'Parva' is an old hybrid of Echeveria purposorum and rumoured Echeveria secunda 'Pumilla' by Eric Walther in 1959. \n \nThe leaves consist of similar markings found on its mother, Echeveria purposorum. It also features a very structural rosette and can grow very tall to create columns of spiky, short leaves. The plant feels and is very strong to the touch. This hybrid blooms in spring and the flowers are yellow of a bell-shape and appear on pink stems. \n \nA very sculptural plant that's easy to grow. It will grow perfect on a bright windowsill or in a terrarium. \n \n

 \n

 \n

Name: Echeveria 'Pulvi-Carn'
Short description: Echeveria 'Pulvi-Carn' is a hybrid of Echeveria pulvinata x Echeveria carnicolor, bred by Cr��e par V. Reiter in 1933. \n \nThis hybrid features hairy, green leaves of a large size that blush a candy-pink under strong light. The rosette will stay in form and will offset readily. It blooms horizontally of a large size, throwing off rows of beautiful pink and yellow bell-shaped flowers. \n \nA great plant to add to a planter or admired in a standalone pot.

Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

 \n
 \nIts a cross between Echeveria agavoides 'Ebony' and Echeveria zaragoza.

 \n
 \nWould sit great in an indoor succulent planter.

Name: Aeonium canariense var. subplanum

Short description: Aloe comosa is a specie of Aloe found on the south western cape of south Africa, it produces a single stem that can turn pinkish in colour in strong light. This Aloe would make a fantastic conservatory plant and become a true feature. Not often seen in cultivation, seed grown at the nursery.

Heart-Leaved Crassula

\nCrassula cordata, is a quick growing succulent that produces�an array of delicate little white flowers on the end of each branch mid to late summer. \n \nIt's also known as the heart-leaved crassula which you can clearly see in the final picture of 4. \n \nThe leaves are bluish green in colour with an attractive red outer leaf margin, each leaf is covered in multiple dots which turn to a striking red colour when exposed to strong light.

Name: Aeonium nobile
Short description:
Aeonium nobile is probably one of the most exciting and dramatic looking Aeonium species on the planet.
 \n
 \nThis Aeonium giant is a must in any collection, a truly stunning Aeonium with its unique growth formation and size not to mention a rewarding stunning floral display.
 \n
 \nWith ideal conditions, Aeonium nobiles can grow up to 3 feet across; each leaf can measure up to 10 inches wide and during the summer the outer leaves turn a beautiful coral colour.
 \n
 \nAfter several years the Aeonium nobiles are mature enough to flower, unlike any other Aeonium they produce a spectacular scarlet-red 3 to 4ft flower spike with thousands of small individual flowers which will be loved by bees and other pollinators for months.
 \n
 \nIt has now become endangered in its natural habitat, making it an extremely rare plant to see in cultivation. Endemic to La Palma, Canary Islands.
 \n
 \nDuring the season of 2018, we proudly had several of our most prized specimens come into full flower, surreal succulents pollinated these to produce the seed for the new stock we now have available. Making this a sustainably sourced rare succulent.
 \n
 \nThey make unbelievable potted succulent plants, a definite must for any collection.
 \n
 \nExtremely drought tolerant, protect from frosts.

Name: Aloe polyphylla (Spiral Aloe) (L)
Short description:
Large Aloe polyphylla, growing in a 3-litre pot. \n \nAll of the Aloes available have been carefully grown from seed and are now growing in a pot measuring 20cm in width. We send the Aloe bare-root, without its pot. \n \nYou will receive the Aloe similar in size to pictures 4 and 5. \n \nThey are incredibly different Aloes due to their unique leaf formation which corkscrews out from the centre of the plant. \n \nSpiral Aloes natural home is of the Maluti Mountains of Lesotho in South Africa, and these Aloes can withstand freezing temperatures (-15?) they can often be under snow in their natural habitat. \n \nThey make a fantastic garden showpiece that can be grown vertically in a rock wall or planter. \nFor best results when planting slightly angle the plant to ensure rainwater runs freely from the crown. \nIt will appreciate feeding throughout the growing season, ensure a free draining soil mix but maintain water as they can be a thirsty plant. \nThey are an extremely fast growing Aloe, perfect UK hardy succulent. \n \nPlant in a south facing aspect and enjoy this beautiful work of nature. \n
You will receive a plant similar in size to pictures 4 and 5 (approx. 20-25cm diameter), the other images are of mature specimens several years old. We send out our Aloes bare root without a pot, as they travel far better in the post.
\n

View our Care Guide for more information on how to look after your Aloe polyphylla.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Euphorbia obesa
Short description:
This species of Euphorbia is a true must for any collection.
 \n
 \nEuphorbia obesa�or otherwise known as the baseball�plant is native to South Africa and loves a good free draining soil mix. To help bring out the attractive colouring and markings grow them in as much light as possible.
 \n
 \nDuring the spring they produce clusters of small flowers on the top of the plant, these sometimes produce seeds that then roll down the side of the succulent and grow alongside the mother.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Echeveria laui
Short description: Echeveria laui is truly one of the most beautiful and remarkable species of Echeveria on the planet, and a real must for any keen succulent growers. \n \nEcheveria laui is native to southern Mexico, located close to the city of Oaxaca. It thrives on little water, whilst clinging to rough rocky outcrops surrounded by other drought-tolerant Succulents such as agaves and yuccas. \n \nThese delightful powder dusted Echeverias grow very slowly. With careful under watering, plenty of light and air movement, especially during the winter, they will thrive. Echeveria laui just looks better and better with age. \n \nCan make a stunning windowsill plant.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Echeveria 'Raindrops'
Short description: A fantastic and magical Echeveria that really does live up to its name, it produces these attractive raindrop like bumps on its leaves. \n \nTo bring out the beautiful purple, red and blue colourings in the leaves, we suggest you grow this Echeveria in strong light and just admire its truly surreal growth form.
Planting Location: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Echeveria xichuensis
Short description: Echeveria xichuensis is definitely one of our favourite species. It produces these marble-like patterns that run through every leaf, and its metallic grey colouring makes it truly stand out amongst our collection, a real joy to grow. \n \nEcheveria xichuensis is native to Mexico in the state of Guantanamera, where it can be found almost camouflaged and clinging to rock crevices away from grazing animals. \n \nThey make fantastic windowsill feature plants once they become established. \n \nA must for any collection.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: x Pachyveria 'Supernova'
Short description:
x Pachyveria 'Supernova', a 2020 introduction, produces layers of velvety-blue slender leaves as the leaves age they explode with an array of different colours, such as yellows and pinks.
 \n
 \nParentage is unknown, but a unique feature on this succulent is the marbling effect on the leaves when mature, suggesting that one of its parents could be Echeveria zaragoza.
 \n
 \nWe have found these plants to be strong growers, with the form and colours of this variety very different than other succulents in the collection.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria simulans Rayones
Short description:
We have a few different varieties of Echeveria simulans, this particular species comes from Rayones located in Mexico. Its distinctly�less wavey than our other variety of simulans�but still just as beautiful. Its blue/green pastel tones with a slight pink tinge really make this a stunner.
 \n
 \nEcheverias are incredibly rewarding plants to grow, they can be grown on there own in a pot, or potted up with other varieties creating beautiful arangments.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Sedum nussbaumerianum
Short description:
This strange but dazzling Sedum is a definite must for any collection. It's striking bright golden-yellow rosettes with a tinge of orange/brown make it really stand out amongst other succulents especially when potted in a mixed planter. Trails with age making it ideal in a hanging succulent planter or basket.
 \n
 \nNative to Mexico. Loves full Sun and hardy down to -4���C, a real winner.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aloe humilis
Short description:
Aloe humilis�or commonly known as the spider Aloe is a species native to the eastern�cape of South Africa, it can be found clinging to rock faces where it survives in the baking sun. It's a very nice compact stemless growing Aloe with these white teeth dotted up and down the leaves, once potted on it produces multiple offsets.
 \n
 \nWhen the Aloe is mature enough it produces these bright orange flowers.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Anacampseros rufescens
Short description:
Anacampseros rufescens�is a low growing clump-forming succulent that goes from a bright green to this chocolatey�brown colouring in strong light, during the spring it produces these bright pink flowers that are eye-catching and attractive.
 \n
 \nIt's an easy succulent to grow and makes a delightful companion�plant in a succulent display. Anacampseros rufescens can withstand temperatures below freezing but we always recommend�protecting your succulents in extreme weather conditions.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aloe juvenna (Tiger Tooth Aloe)
Short description:
We love this quirky little Aloe, it produces this vibrant bright pale green rosettes�covered�in these protective semi-soft�thorns that are definitely�less harmful to touch than to look at.
 \n
 \nOnce potted on this succulent will produce offsets from the base of the plant, and if grown in strong light with little feed or water the leaves will produce an attractive�red colouring.
 \n
 \nThey make perfect houseplants for the south, east or west facing windowsills.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Aloe vera
Short description:
Aloe vera is probably the most common of all aloes. It's medicinal properties and easiness to grow indoors make it a must for any household.
 \n
 \nPot on into a good succulent mix, feed in the spring and keep indoors on a bright windowsill out of the direct midday sun, water when the soil becomes dry to touch.
 \n
 \nIf you are to take any of the leaves for medicinal purposes, it is always best to use the older lower leaves as the Aloe will recover better for any future use.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Paradise'
Short description:
This beautiful Aeonium 'Paradise' is an Aeonium ciliatum hybrid. It is probably one of the most attractive new green varieties we have released for some time. It's rich glaucus lime coloured leaves and this distinct red outer margin is really a sight to enjoy.
 \n
 \nIt will grow quickly once re-potted, producing multiple uniform rosettes. It makes a fantastic potted succulent. Definitely a winner in our eyes and a must for displaying at future garden shows.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Emerald Ice'
Short description:
Aeonium 'Emerald Ice' is a wonderful and beautiful hybrid created by Renee O'Connell.
 \n
 \nThis variegated beauty is incredibly rewarding as it always looks perfect no matter what time of the year.
 \n
 \nEach lime coloured leaf produces these delightful white margins, during the spring you will see this slightly�pink blushing to the older leaves.
 \n
 \nFor best growth results keep the Aeonium out of the midday sun especially during the summer, water when the soil dries.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Texas Rose'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Texas Rose' is a delightful variety that produces an attractive pale blue rose cupped rosette, and if grown�in high light it produces a hint of pink on the outer leaves, �occasionally if the conditions are right the whole�plant can turn light pink.
 \n
 \nIt is believed�to be an Echeveria runyonii�hybrid.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Aloe camperi 'Cornuta'
Short description:
Aloe camperi 'Cornuta' is a highly sought after and beautiful looking Aloe that produces these attractive long emerald-green leaves. The outer leaf margins are covered in these fine orange-tinted teeth that cover all the way to the tip of the leaves. The leaves are also covered in these delicate little white flecks and when grown in high light levels they produce these fiery orange tips.
 \n
 \nThe Aloe camperi 'Cornuta' makes a fantastic houseplant for indoors and grows very nicely on a bright sunny windowsill.
 \n
 \nThe plants for sale are growing nicely in a 9cm pot and are of similar size to the one in the picture.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: x Graptoveria 'Bashful'
Short description:
Graptoveria 'Bashful' is a happy fast-growing succulent that produces these colourful deep red outer leaves. It also keeps its almost lime-green centres as it grows.
 \n
 \nThey grow well on their own or with other succulents. We like to use them in miniature succulent display planters as they grow very well when potted with other varieties such as Crassulas and Haworthias.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria lilacina (Frilly Form)
Short description: An unusual variant to the Echeveria lilacina. It is the first plant to turn to frilly form in our nursery. It inherits all the lilacina colouring of chalky white. Can turn pink under strong light.

Name: Echeveria 'Neon Breaker'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Neon Breaker' is definitely one of the most spectacular and colourful hybrids in our collection. During the season it will change in colour from bright pink to a deep purple. One of the best features of this succulent is its attractive wavy leaf margins that produce a deeper colouring when introduced to strong light.
 \n
 \nAs you can see in pictures 3 and 4 we have one of our beautiful mother plants, our mother plants are grown in slightly�less light with more nutrients, growing them this way shows off their range in colours.
 \n
 \nA great houseplant for a sunny windowsill, also ideal outside potted�up with other succulents creating�a beautiful companion�planter for a patio or garden. Succulent planters require�little or no maintenance during the summer season, just enjoy and admire.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Echeveria 'Pastel Perfection'
Short description: We love this very special plant 'Pastel Perfection', just looks amazing and stands out in a crowd of succulents. Boasting these pale blue leaves that run in a perfectly symmetrical formation.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Sempervivum 'Armageddon'
Short description:
2019 introduction.
 \n
 \nSempervivum 'Armageddon' is a fantastic chocolatey-brown coloured sempervivum. We use this plant a lot when planting out mixed planters as it adds an interesting colour to a display.
 \n
 \nSempervivums come in a fantastic array of colours, form and texture. They make outstanding garden plants either planted straight out into a rockery or simply planted in pots outside all year round.
 \n
 \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C and even lower in some cases. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, we recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply re pot with a slow-release fertiliser feed mixed into the compost, this will encourage the succulents to produce many new offsets.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Oddity'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Oddity' produces these oddly shaped green sucker like leaves with burgundy tips. Strangely beautiful but a very easy and rewarding sempervivum to grow.
 \n
 \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, and recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply re pot with a slow-release fertiliser feed mixed into the compost, this will encourage the succulents to produce many new offsets.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria purpusorum
Short description:
The fabulous, slow-growing Echeveria purpusorum is a distinctive species from Mexico. It's attractive deep green leaves with flecks of red that resemble the skin of a little lizard, they can withstand high temperatures and look quite pointy and sharp to touch but are in fact quite delicate and kind.
 \n
 \nIn it's natural habitat, it grows on rocky outcrops which allow the water to pass through the root system very quickly.
 \n
 \nThey grow well on sunny windowsills. Use free-draining soil mix and water after soil drys.
 \n
 \nDuring the growing season, it's always advised to feed Echeverias as this will encourage more flowers and a faster growth rate. Ensure as much sunlight gets to the plants as possible as this will encourage them to grow naturally without having to reach for the light.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Crassula 'Moonglow'
Short description:
Crassula 'Moonglow' is a truly beautiful variety with its sculptural form and dusty green/grey colouring. Their fleshy interlocking leaves and their towering form make it look like a miniature skyscraper.
 \n
 \nMid to late summer they produce a red flower from the centre crown of the rosette and new offsets will appear from the lower leaves in time.
 \n
 \nIt is believed to be a hybrid of Crassula deceptor�v.�arta�cross Crassula falcata.
 \n
 \nThey make perfect windowsill plants and love growing outside during the summer.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria tencho
Short description:
2019 introduction.
 \nEcheveria tencho is a wonderful species from Mexico.
 \n
 \nIn high light levels, they produce these vibrantly bright orange leaves with striking lime green centres.
 \nWe have found this variety to be very easy to grow. In time it will produce multiple tall flower stems.
 \n
 \nVery unique and different growth form from many other Echeveria.
Planting Location: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria fimbriata
Short description: The Echeveria fimbriata is a fast growing, strong succulent. With it's beautiful burgundy colouring and robust leaves it will make anyone's collection special. This tall-growing species features waxy green to red leaves. Given the space, this succulent can grow to a tall sculptural specimen.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Dudleya farinosa
Short description:
Dudleya farinosa is a beautiful and highly prized species from California.
 \n
 \nIt's covered in this white powder-like bloom that protects it from the strong Californian sun. They are extremely drought tolerant and are very happy to have little or no water during the summer months.
 \nCommonly know as the powdery live-forever succulent. Hardy down to -6�C.
 \n
 \nGreat outdoors in the winter as a mature specimen.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Cotyledon orbiculata undulata
Short description:
Cotyledon orbiculata undulata or otherwise known as the silver crown is a very sculptural succulent. As you can see it produces these incredible oyster shell-like leaves that neatly overlap each other. Each leaf has this silver like dust (bloom) that protects it against strong sunlight.
 \n
 \nIn time they will produce offsets. They also produce a beautiful array of orange and yellow bell-shaped flowers on a tall flower stem in mid to late summer.
 \n
 \nAll Cotyledon species originated in South Africa and seem to be semi-hardy. Cotyledon orbiculata has been known to survive temperatures as low as -6�C for short periods of time.
 \n
 \nThey make awesome potted succulents on their own or you could try them with a mix of other succulents such as Echeveria, crassula and sempervivums to create your own little low maintenance succulent landscape.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria agavoides 'Romeo'
Short description:
Echeveria agavoides 'Romeo' is a truly stunning succulent that is thought to be a mutation from Echeveria agavoides 'Corderoyi', originally found in Germany.
 \n
 \nThey grow quite slowly but these beautiful specimens are well worth the wait. When the Echeveria agavoides 'Romeo' is fully mature they can fill a 30cm wide bowl.
 \nThey make fantastic feature plants and you can't beat the outstanding colouring in their leaves. A must for any collection. They make an ideal houseplant for a sunny windowsill.
 \nWater when soil dries.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria 'Belle Etoile'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Belle Etoile' is an attractive cross of Echeveria purpusorum and another unknown Echeveria species. It grows in its own unique star-shaped form with similar colouring and markings as Echeveria purpusorum. The leaves are slim with these sharp-looking points but are in fact very soft to touch.
 \n
 \nGrows well on a bright sunny windowsill in a pot, water when the soil dries.
 \n
 \nFlowers May/June.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Blood'
Short description:
Aeonium 'Blood' is our very own hybrid. Shown for the first time in our gold medal-winning exhibit at RHS Hampton Court in July 2019. This stunning quick-growing variety is a cross between Aeonium 'Maximus' and Aeonium 'Voodoo'.
 \n
 \nThe early spring sunshine brings out this dazzling rich blood-like colouring in its rosettes which later darken in the summer, as the light levels intensify the leaves turn a deep dark red. We have found it to be an incredibly fast-growing Aeonium just like its parentage. It will produce layers of rosettes at intervals as it grows to create this tree-like form in as little as three years.
 \n
 \nFor best results when growing Aeoniums pot on or feed in early spring. If a plant is well-rooted and established in a pot feed with a 3 or 6-month slow-release fertiliser. It is important that Aeoniums have a good root system before adding any new fertiliser to the soil or compost. If the plants don't anchor down in search for new nutrients then they can become top-heavy and become unstable in a pot or planter.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Echeveria 'Macabeana'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Macabeana' is a very rare succulent with a unique star-shaped form made up of pointed red-tipped leaves. This hybrid is suspected that one of the parents is Echeveria agavoides.
 \n
 \nOne of the unique features of this attractive succulent is that in all the years we have grown it, we have never seen it flower.� It stays very compact and offsets from the centre of the plant, creating multi-headed clusters. It will produce a vibrant red colouring on the leaf margins under intense light.
 \n
 \nThe perfect feature plant for a windowsill or pot.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria lindsayana
Short description:
Echeveria lindsayana has been used by ourselves and other breeders as a parent plant to many hybrids due to its great form and colouration.
 \n
 \nThis attractive form is very strong and unlike some echeveria that replenish their leaves regularly this one holds its lower leaves for a long time so mature specimens can grow quite large with great colouration on the older leaves. It will also get a brighter and deeper red colouration when grown in strong light and more of a 'dusty' pink the rest of the time.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \n

Name: Echeveria hoveyi variegata
Short description: This large growing species is a very bright coloured plant. The Echeveria hoveyi variegata features a green leaf, pink tinges and yellow striping. The leaf shape resembles a bear paw. Very unusual succulent and will stand out in any collection or in a group planting with other succulents.

Name: Echeveria 'Debbie'
Short description: Echeveria 'Debbie' has a strong and very uniform rosette consisting of curved rounded leaves covered in short ridged hairs. This plant holds its lower leaves longer than other Echeverias, giving them a chance to colour up to orange and even bright red in stronger light. It is a dark green and has a more open form when actively growing. Ideal as a standalone feature in its own pot and also planted with other succulents.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Europa'
Short description: A 2020 introduction Echeveria 'Europa', a hybrid of Echeveria albicans and Echeveria lindsayana, has a strong geometric form of crested round leaves boasting a ghostly icy-green colouration fading to pale-pink on the mature lower leaves. Great as a standalone feature plant or can be used as a striking contrast in amongst darker coloured succulents.
Categories: Echeveria, Echeveria > Echeveria A-J, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria pulvinata 'Ruby Glow'
Short description:
This gem, Echeveria 'Ruby Glow' produces the brightest and the most intense red colouring on its outer leaf margins, the leaves are soft and velvety to touch, in time it will develop into a beautiful specimen with multiple offsets.
 \n
 \nEcheveria 'Ruby Glow's make fantastic pot plants, they grow well indoors on a sunny windowsill and can be moved outside during the summer.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aloe sinkatana (Sudan Aloe)
Short description: This perennial succulent is perfect for a windowsill. It grows to around 30-40cm and produces a beautiful yellow flower. The leaves are thick, with beautiful colours ranging from green to orange. It also features orange teeth around each of the leaves.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Gasteria acinacifolia
Short description: The largest of the Gasteria genus. This species features beautiful big orange and green flowers. This plant can grow up to 75cm, making it a perfect showcase plant for a succulent bed. It also features big tongue-like green and spotty leaves.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Pachyphytum oviferum x Sedum morganianum
Short description:
This incredible hybrid of two exceptionally different species is one you can't miss. Inheriting the big pale leaves of the Pachyphytum oviferum and the beautiful pale green essence of the Sedum morganianum plus it's trailing features makes this a very inspiring combination of two greats.
 \n
 \nWorks well with other plants as a multi-trailing feature on the edge of a pot. Also perfect for hanging pots.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Echeveria glauca 'Silver Lining'
Short description:
Often mistaken as Echeveria 'Imbricata' this Echeveria glauca 'Silver Lining' is a definite must for any collection.
 \n
 \nAs the plant ages, it produces the most stunning tight-forming blue rosettes with fine red tips on the ends of each leaf.
 \n
 \nWe love to use this succulent on mass planted underneath our tall branching Aeoniums in our RHS show gardens. With it being a cultivar of Echeveria glauca, we have found it to be a vigorous grower. It can survive colder and wetter conditions more so than other Echeverias.
 \n
 \nIt looks terrific either potted on its own or in a mixed succulent container.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria 'Blondie'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Blondie' is a fast-growing, frilly succulent. It is a pale green colour with large fleshy leaves. Will feature red tips under stress of high light levels.
 \n
 \nIts unique pale colouring looks excellent as part of a collection. This hybrid works better as a large standalone specimen.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Kalanchoe fedtschenkoi (Lavender Scallops)
Short description:
Kalanchoe fedtschenkoi is a beautiful, colourful plant. A very fast grower. This species features big, beautiful, dark-red flowers that droop off a complex flower stem.
 \n
 \nNative to Madagascar, this stunning variety also features giant, scallop-like leaves ranging from green, yellow and red. We recommend strong light levels to bring out an even better red colouring. Works really well when planted with other succulents in a container or pot.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Kalanchoe fedtschenkoi variegata
Short description: Kalanchoe fedtschenkoi variegata is a great addition to your collection. With it's sculptural scallop-like leaves, it fits into any assortment. This variegated species features a brilliant green, pink, white and yellow colouring and really stands out under strong light levels. Will produce red edges under stress.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Kalanchoe tomentosa 'Dorothy Brown'
Short description:
Commonly known as the Panda Plant, this extraordinary variety of Kalanchoe tomentosa.
 \n
 \nIt consists of thick, brown furry leaves which are pleasant to touch, another of the�outstanding features of this succulents is the chocolatey colouring.
 \n
 \nLike a lot of fascinating species on this planet Kalanchoe's are native to the magical island of Madagascar.
 \n
 \nRecommended indoors. You can plant it in a pot with other succulents to bring out it's contrasting features.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Compton Carousel' 1
Short description:
Echeveria �Compton Carousel�
 \n
 \nThis extremely sought-after succulent is a variegated Echeveria �Imbricata�. A clumping succulent that features a beautiful, strong variegation on the blue/grey leaves. Will have hints of pink under stress. Like the �Imbricata�, it features circular, pointy leaves on a tight rosette. The flowers are orange and yellow that will appear on a stem that can grow to almost a metre in height.
 \n
 \nThis particular specimen approximately measures 12cm in diameter and 4cm in height.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Rare Plant Fair

Name: Echeveria 'Compton Carousel' 2
Short description:
Echeveria �Compton Carousel�
 \n
 \nThis extremely sought-after succulent is a variegated Echeveria �Imbricata�. A clumping succulent that features a beautiful, strong variegation on the blue/grey leaves. Will have hints of pink under stress. Like the �Imbricata�, it features circular, pointy leaves on a tight rosette. The flowers are orange and yellow that will appear on a stem that can grow to almost a metre in height.
 \n
 \nThis particular specimen approximately measures 12cm in diameter and 4cm in height.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Rare Plant Fair

Name: Aloe haworthioides miniature
Short description: Aloe haworthioides� \n \nThis species of Aloe is native to Madagascar and named for the spiny hairs found on the leaves that resemble that of a Haworthia species. This is a small formed species that does not grow on a stem, but instead forms clumping offsets sporting orange flowers in autumn. \n \nThis particular specimen approximately measures 10cm in diameter and 5cm in height.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Rare Plant Fair

Name: Gasteria marmorata white variegate form 2
Short description:
Gasteria marmorata variegata form 2
 \n
 \nThis Gasteria has big, green leaves with a white variegation. A slow growing, clumping succulent that is perfect for a north facing windowsill. They can grow equally as well in full sun as shade, making it a very versatile succulent.
 \n
 \nThis particular specimen approximately measures 9cm in diameter and 8cm in height.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Rare Plant Fair

Name: Echeveria agavoides 'Ebony' (L)
Short description: The plant you will receive is the same size or bigger than the plant in the picture which measures: \n \nDiameter - 12cm \n \nHeight - 6cm \n \nEcheveria agavoides 'Ebony' was originally�found growing in Mexico by John Trager and Myron Kimnach, it was released in cultivation�in the year 2000. \n \nIt quickly became one of the most sought-after Echeveria's around and became incredibly popular in Asia, with the price for just one plant costing well over �300. \n \nThey are notoriously slow to offset but easily one of the most beautiful and rewarding Echeveria's around, the most attractive feature has to be their pale green-grey leaves set off by their almost black outer leaf margins. \n \nThey are stunningly beautiful and structural succulents that rarely encounter any problems with pests or diseases. \n \nThey make fantastic houseplants as they are so robust and easy to care for, just place them in a bright/sunny windowsill and water when the soil dries, feed with a slow-release feed in the spring. They love our summers so growing them outdoors in a pot or in the garden in full sun will show off their full potential an intensify the dark outer leaf margins. \n \nIf kept�dry outside during the winter they are hardy down to -7. \n \n  \n \n

Name: Haworthia margaritifera (Pearl Plant)
Short description: Originating from South Africa. Haworthia margaritifera, also known as the Pearl Plant, is a clumping species. It features white speckles on it's tentacle-like leaves. A very fleshy plant that offsets freely from the base.

Short description: This variation of arboreum is so unusual due to its extreme offsetting, even from a small cutting. The colours range from green, fading to dark black towards the end of the leaves. Perfect potted plant.

Short description: Native to South Africa, the Crassula lactea is an unusual green species with white freckles that outline each leaf. Offsets regularly from the base. Blooms in the winter with beautiful white flowers. A great beginner plant due to its lack of pests and fast-growing properties. Perfect for hanging baskets.

Name: Sedum cuspidatum
Short description:
Native to Mexico, this unusual Sedum is hardy down to -6�C, making it perfect for adding colour to your garden all year round.
 \n
 \nThis species features yellow and green pointed leaves but will blush red during high light levels and when stressed.
 \n
 \nThe rosette is very neat and offsets freely to fill any empty garden space you may want covering. Would also look great in a hanging pot.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Senecio peregrinus (String of Dolphins)
Short description:
The highly prized and rare Senecio peregrinus or more commonly known as 'String of Dolphins'.
 \n
 \nThis succulent species makes a fantastic trailing house plant and is a quick-grower that always creates a talking point amongst friends and family.
 \n
 \nGrow in semi-shade and water when the soil dries.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria 'Matrix'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Matrix' is our own exciting frilly hybrid, previewed for the first time in our RHS Gold winning garden at Hampton Court in 2019.
 \n
 \nA fast grower which produces these intense deep-red colours that last all year round. This hybrid can grow to the size of a basketball if given the space.
 \n
 \nEcheveria 'Matrix' would make the perfect potted succulent for your patio in the summer months and great as a stand-alone specimen in any collection.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Pachyphytum werdermannii
Short description:
Native to the mountains in Mexico, the Pachyphytum werdermannii features long pebble-like leaves of star-shaped form. Mature plants will have a downward curved leaf
 \n
 \nThe beauty of this plant is the vast colour changes throughout the year, a newly potted specimen would be of a green to blue colour, whereas the more stressed plant can go to a rose-pink.
 \n
 \nSits perfectly in a multi succulent planter.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Crassula pyramidalis
Short description:
Crassula pyramidalis, also known as the Pagoda Mini Jade, is a slow-growing sculptural succulent.
 \n
 \nIt features a square-shaped column of tightly packed thin leaves that will blush red under intense light.
 \n
 \nThis species is monocarpic (dies back after flowering), but pups will grow from the base. Not only does it offset after flowering, but it will offset multiple times during the season to create a fantastic sculpture.
 \n
 \nThe flowers are white/pink and create a pompom-like look on the top of the succulent.
 \n
 \nThis unusual plant makes a perfect standalone plant on a windowsill due to its drought-tolerant characteristics. Would also make a brilliant contrast in a mixed succulent planter.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade

Name: x Sedeveria 'Jet Beads'
Short description:
x Sedeveria 'Jet Beads', also known as Jet Beads Stonecrop, is a hybrid of Sedum stahlii and Echeveria affinis.

Inheriting its dark colours from the Echeveria affinis and its tall-growing factor from the Sedum stahlii, its a perfect combination for adding contrast and texture to your planter. Flowers yellow in the summer and can also go a maroon-red under high light levels. This variety will grow to a maximum of only 4 inches tall, so it will never outgrow its companions. Offsets regularly.

Recommended to be planted in a succulent planter, a hanging basket or windowsill.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Dry Shade, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Graptopetalum paraguayense
Short description:
Graptopetalum paraguayense, also known as the Ghost Plant, is a clumping species native to Tamaulipas, Mexico.
 \n
 \nThis spectacular hardy variety features pale-green colouring when young and a more ghostly-white (hence the name) towards maturity. It offsets readily and flowers in the spring with beautiful red-spotted white flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect for planting with other succulents or as a standalone feature in your garden. Hanging pot highly recommended.
 \n
 \n
Planting Location: Green Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Windowsill

Name: x Graptoveria 'Koala'
Short description:
X Graptoveria 'Koala' is a truly beautiful hybrid of �X Graptoveria 'Opalina', we have found it to be a very strong and easy succulent to grow and once repotted will grow to a good size. It's has the most attractive silver foliage that works incredibly well when planted in a mixed succulent display.
 \n
 \nWe have grown X Graptoveria 'Koala' for a few years now and we have found that it does particularly well in a hanging basket, clinging on and looking incredibly beautiful like the amazing Koala itself.
 \n
 \nIt's definitely one we will be using in our vertical show gardens.
 \n
 \n
Planting Location: Branching, Trailing
Colour: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria 'Moroccan Sunset'
Short description:
A magnificent Echeveria colorata cultivar that has been in the collection for well over 10 years until its release in 2020. The colourings of the Echeveria 'Moroccan Sunset' are absolutely beautiful and look far more intense the larger the plant gets.
 \n
 \nIt can also grow into a giant of an Echeveria growing to the size of a basketball once fully mature.
 \n
 \nLoves full sun with a top layer of grit or small stones to aid drainage, feed during the growing months with a liquid seaweed or slow release pellets.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Rock Hopper'
Short description: A cracking, almost stemless succulent, believed to be a naturalised garden hybrid of Aeonium Cuneatum x Aeonium 'Barbatum'. \n \nIt's a fantastic plant for exposed sunny locations (stone wall) and clumps forming hundreds of similar-sized rosettes. We have grown this hybrid for well over 15 years and have yet to see it in flower. \n \nA fantastic feature plant.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Azrael'
Short description: A hybrid bred by Erwin Geiger in Germany. Seed parent of Sempervivum 'Bronze Pastel'.� \n \nThis plant features pointed leaves with small hairs, and like its parent, it has a dark appearance under high light levels, adding a great shade to your succulent planter. Will offset very regularly. \n \nPerfect for a mixed Sempervivum bowl that can be placed on a full-sun windowsill or outside. This specimen would also be a perfect texture to contrast against other succulent varieties. \n \n
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Agave parryi var. truncata
Short description:
Also known as the Artichoke Agave, the Agave parryi var. truncata is one of the most frost hardy varieties of Agave due to its low water needs. Can handle temperatures as low as -12�C.
 \n
 \nThis beautiful specimen features deep sea-blue large leaves with dark purple spikes on the tips and leaf edges. Can grow to a big size and offsets freely. A very tough plant so please be careful when handling.
 \n
 \nWould fit perfectly in a rockery and add an amazing texture to any garden.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Othonna capensis 'Ruby Necklace'
Short description:
Othonna capensis, also known as 'Ruby Necklace' is a distinct species from South Africa.
 \n
 \nThis trailing succulent features long purple stems of green bead-like fleshy leaves. It will bloom in spring with beautiful daisy-like yellow flowers.
 \n
 \nA must for a hanging pot or wall. Is a great indoor and outdoor plant.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Agave victoriae-reginae
Short description:
Also known as the royal Agave, visually stunning and incredibly hardy this popular variety is native to Mexico. Unlike many of its relatives, it only has spines on the very tips of its leaves.
 \n
 \nThe most unique and beautiful feature of this succulent has to be the white stripe running through each of its leaves, and these become more pronounced with age.
 \n
 \nAwarded the RHS Award of Garden Merit for resistance to pests and diseases, grows well in the UK climate.
 \n
 \nLike most Agaves, it is best to keep as dry as possible during the winter months, primarily if being grown outdoor.
 \n
 \nAgave victoriae-reginae can survive temperatures as low as -10�C if kept dry.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Agave americana 'Variegata'
Short description:
This quick-growing agave puts on a fantastic show and makes an excellent feature plant in a rockery or succulent display.
 \n
 \nWe often use this plant in our displays at the nursery as adds great visual interest and contrasts very well with other succulents.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Agave americana 'Mediopicta Alba'
Short description:
Agave americana 'Mediopicta Alba' is one of the most attractive and desirable Agave variegates around, it has the most alluring cream stripe running up the centre of each of its grey/blue leaves.
 \n
 \nA robust grower that makes the most stunning architectural pot plant, they can grow to a reasonable size.
 \n
 \nPot on during the spring into a free-draining gritty succulent compost, mix with a little bit of slow-release fertilizer.
 \n
 \nProtect from winter wet.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Aeonium tabuliforme x nobile
Short description:
Our very own stunning cultivar of Aeonium tabuliforme crossed Aeonium nobile, it produces the most beautiful symmetrical single large green rosette. When fully grown it measures well over 50cm in diameter, the plant is quite short and compact growing no more than 30cm in height.
 \n
 \nEye-catching succulent and can be truly appreciated when planted on there own in a pot. Ideally suited to morning or afternoon sun and once repotted can put on a lot of growth in a short period.
 \n
 \nLimited stock available.
Planting Location: Single Stem
Growth Form: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Angorite'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Angorite' is a fast-growing, long-leaved variety. It features pale green colourings with hints of fiery-orange under high light levels.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a rockery or pot.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Raven Heart'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Raven Heart' is a dark-red variety with large wing-like leaves. It will get darker and darker throughout the year.
 \n
 \nThe perfect plant to add contrast to your succulent planter or garden rockery.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Sumplonstern'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Sumplonstern' is a compact variety that ranges all shades of green throughout the year. Darkening under high light levels. It also features brown tips, giving it a fierce look.
 \n
 \nPerfect for any rockery or outside planter.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Star Burst'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Star Burst' takes its name from its dark qualities. It features long, deep-purple leaves. Grows fast and offsets readily.
 \n
 \nWould add a striking contrast to a succulent planter.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Pip'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Pip' is an interesting variety due to its patterned colouring. It has a dark-purple leaf that features elements of green. Grows to a big size.
 \n
 \nRecommended on its own or as a feature in a succulent rockery.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Perfect'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Perfect' takes its name from its beautiful rosette form and colour. One of our favourite Sempervivums. A deep-green coloured variety that features purple tips.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a succulent planter or outdoor rockery/pot.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Logan Rock' (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nA branching Aeonium bred by Trewidden Nursery (now Penberth Plants), also a Chelsea Flower Show plant of the year finalist 2012. Purple rosettes with a green centre will form a mound of rosettes approx. 45cm height and width.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium 'Maximus' (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nA 2016 hybrid, Aeonium 'Maximus' really is something a bit different. It forms a cluster of rosettes around a larger central rosette (20-25cm in height by 15-2cm diameter). It has a mid-green colouring with striations on the underside of its leaves with striking slender sword-like leaves. It is quite free-flowering with attractive yellow flowers on branching flower stems to 50-60cm. Its parentage is A. cuneatum x A. simsii.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium 'Sunburst' (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nThis Aeonium has beautiful variegation in the leaves and pink tinges to the leaf margins in high light levels. It is thought to be a variegate of A. davidbramwellii.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium O-T, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Ice Warrior' (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nAeonium 'Ice Warrior' was bred for it's hardiness, hence the name. Whilst not invincible against freezing temperatures it will put up a brave fight to make it through. The parent plants are Aeonium smithii x Aeonium 'Cyclops' both of which can withstand temperatures below freezing. The underside to the leaves show distinct characteristics of Aeonium smithii, you will see these markings consistently in the hardier varieties of Aeonium.

Short description:
The specimen you receive will be approximately 30cm wide and 28cm height from the soil.
 \n
 \nAlso known as the royal Agave, visually stunning and incredibly hardy this popular variety is native to Mexico. Unlike many of its relatives, it only has spines on the very tips of its leaves.
 \n
 \nThe most unique and beautiful feature of this succulent has to be the white stripe running through each of its leaves, and these become more pronounced with age.
 \n
 \nAwarded the RHS Award of Garden Merit for resistance to pests and diseases, grows well in the UK climate.
 \n
 \nLike most Agaves, it is best to keep as dry as possible during the winter months, primarily if being grown outdoor.
 \n
 \nAgave victoriae-reginae can survive temperatures as low as -10�C if kept dry.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Aeonium tabuliforme (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nThis Aeonium has a really stunning saucer-like form with scale-like interlocking leaves. It is native to Tenerife and often found growing vertically on cliffs. It can grow up to 40cm diameter in cultivation.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium O-T, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Cornish Tribute' (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nAeonium 'Cornish Tribute' is a hybrid bred by Trewidden Nursery and made the top 20 in the new plant competition at RHS Chelsea Flower Show 2012. It is a compact, low growing plant that grows to a height of approx. 25cm and 45cm diameter.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium A-J, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Aeonium nobile (L)
Short description:
Grown in a 1 litre(13cm) pot .
 \n
 \nAeonium nobile is probably one of the most exciting and dramatic looking Aeonium species on the planet.
 \n
 \nThis Aeonium giant is a must in any collection, a truly stunning Aeonium with its unique growth formation and size not to mention a rewarding stunning floral display.
 \n
 \nWith ideal conditions, Aeonium nobiles can grow up to 3 feet across; each leaf can measure up to 10 inches wide and during the summer the outer leaves turn a beautiful coral colour.
 \n
 \nAfter several years the Aeonium nobiles are mature enough to flower, unlike any other Aeonium they produce a spectacular scarlet-red 3 to 4ft flower spike with thousands of small individual flowers which will be loved by bees and other pollinators for months.
 \n
 \nIt has now become endangered in its natural habitat, making it an extremely rare plant to see in cultivation. Endemic to La Palma, Canary Islands.
 \n
 \nDuring the season of 2018, we proudly had several of our most prized specimens come into full flower, surreal succulents pollinated these to produce the seed for the new stock we now have available. Making this a sustainably sourced rare succulent.
 \n
 \nThey make unbelievable potted succulent plants, a definite must for any collection.
 \n
 \nExtremely drought tolerant, protect from frosts.
Categories: Aeonium, Aeonium > Aeonium K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Blushing Beauty' (L)
Short description: This U.S. hybrid Aeonium has beautiful pink/red 'blushing' leaves and branches freely to form a dense, branched specimen.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium A-J, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Echeveria 'Moonshadow' (L)
Short description:
This specimen was grown in a 1 litre (13cm pot).
 \n
 \nThis beautiful Echeveria was showcased on BBC Gardeners' world in May 2018.
 \n
 \nThe delightful Echeveria cultivar, it is a cross between Echeveria 'Mexican Giant' and Echeveria affinis.
 \n
 \nThe leaves have a lovely coating of white powder known as bloom, and if rubbed reveals a darker leaf underneath.
 \n
 \nIt�s a quick and strong grower, one of our most prized new cultivars. There�s nothing like this in the whole collection, you won't be disappointed.
 \n
 \nIt makes a beautifully potted succulent for a windowsill and produces vibrant attractive flowers during the summer.
Categories: Echeveria, Echeveria > Echeveria K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Senecio serpens (large) ARCHIVE
Short description:
This specimen was grown in a 1 litre pot (13cm).
 \n
 \nSenecio serpens, also known as Blue Chalksticks or Dead Man's Fingers, is a species from the Western Cape province of South Africa.
 \n
 \nIt is an attractive small succulent that features powdery blue-green fleshy leaves and branches from the base, forming a pot plant to about 25-30cm or planted in the ground. It will root from the stems and spread.
 \n
 \nPerfect for an indoor succulent planter. Adds great colour and height to your collection.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Senecio serpens (L)
Short description:
This specimen was grown in a 1 litre pot (13cm).
 \n
 \nSenecio serpens, also known as Blue Chalksticks or Dead Man's Fingers, is a species from the Western Cape province of South Africa.
 \n
 \nIt is an attractive small succulent that features powdery blue-green fleshy leaves and branches from the base, forming a pot plant to about 25-30cm or planted in the ground. It will root from the stems and spread.
 \n
 \nPerfect for an indoor succulent planter. Adds great colour and height to your collection.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Delosperma haworthii (L)
Short description:
Delosperma haworthii is definitely one of our favourite trailing succulents in the whole collection, it has the most amazing colour and shape to the flower head.
 \n
 \nIt's fascinating how the flowers preserve energy by closing up at night and then the following day reopen to the delight of all the bees and butterflies.
 \n
 \nFast growing with the most incredible floral display of bright pinky/purple flowers. Its common name is Ice Plant and was previously botanically known as Lampranthus and Mesembryanthemum.
 \n
 \nNative to South Africa.
 \n
 \nThey love plenty of water and feed during the growing season.
 \n
 \nPlant straight away and water well.
Categories: Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Trailing Succulents
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Agave parrasana
Short description:
Agave parrasana, also known as the Cabbage Head Agave, is a cracking species native to East Mexico.
 \n
 \nIt grows a compact growing form with a maximum height of 60cm and width of 50cm-60cm.
 \n
 \nThis Agave is one of the hardiest species and if kept as dry as possible during the winter months can survive temperatures to at least -12.
 \n
 \nOne of the most attractive features of this Agave are the fingerprints left behind by the newly developing leaves.
 \n
 \nThe plant you will receive is a 6-year-old seed grown very healthy specimen, measuring roughly 12cm-14cm across and 10cm-12cm high.
 \n
 \nAgaves make fantastic pot plants that like to be fed during the growing season, they require plenty of drainage if kept outside all winter.
 \n
 \nPlant at a slight angle so that water can drain from the crown and always top-dress with good quality gravel or grit to ensure excellent drainage.
 \n
 \nWould fit perfectly in a rockery and add an amazing texture to any garden.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Durango' (L)
Short description:
The specimen you receive was grown in a 1 litre/13cm pot.
 \n
 \nAeonium �Durango� is new cultivar that puts on a beautiful display of multiple heads as it grows, the leaves are velvety red which will turn green during the winter.
 \n
 \nIt will eventually grow between 2 and 3 feet high with a 2 foot spread.
 \n
 \nIt makes a fantastic pot plant.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium A-J, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Delosperma copiosus (L)
Short description:
Delosperma copiosus, also known as 'Ice Plant', is a more-plump variety. It features pink/purple flowers every spring.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a rockery, creating a sculptural trailing plant all-year-round.
 \n
 \nNative to South Africa.
 \n
 \nThey love plenty of water and feed during the growing season.
 \n
 \nPlant straight away and water well.
Categories: Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Trailing Succulents
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Delosperma 'Tresco Red' (L)
Short description:
Lampranthus 'Tresco Red' features beautiful fire-red flowers in the spring/summer.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a rockery, creating a sculptural trailing plant all-year-round.
 \n
 \nNative to South Africa.
 \n

Name: Chelsea-Look Bundle
Short description: Get the Chelsea Flower Show look with our combination Aeonium Pack. 10% off when all 3 plants are purchased together.
