Name: Sempervivum 'Kitty's'
Short description: A beautiful Sempervivum cultivar with pink-red outer leaves merging to a green centre.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum calcareum 'Extra'
Short description:
Sempervivum calcareum 'Extra' is an absolutely stunning variety, with its silver-grey foliage and black outer margins makes this one of the most beautiful and architectural.
 \n
 \nIt was originally grown as a natural form of Sempervivum calcareum, but because of its distant appearance and Beauty is was given the name Extra by Howard Wills.
 \n
 \nSempervivums come in a fantastic array of colours, form and texture. They make outstanding garden plants either planted straight out into a rockery or simply planted in pots outside all year round.
 \n
 \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C and even lower in some cases. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, we recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply repot with a slow-release fertiliser feed mixed into the compost, this will encourage the succulents to produce many new offsets.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sedum 'Dark Magic'
Short description:
Sedum 'Dark Magic' produces multiple branches of deep purple foliage with each branch producing an abundance of nectar rich dark pink flowers late summer, the perfect late feast for the bees before winter.
 \n
 \nThey will die back at the end of summer and come back bigger and better the following spring.
 \n
 \nSedums are know for there hardiness and this variety is also incredibly hardy surviving temperature as low -20 if not more.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Haworthia magnifica v. atrofusca mutant
Short description:
Haworthia magnifica v. atrofusca mutant is an exciting variety with stunning translucent leaves to aid photosynthesis, the markings on the glossy leaves are particularly striking. Rarely offered and of a good age, you will receive either the plant in the picture or something very similar.
 \n
 \nSize of plant approx 7cm across and 3cm high.
 \n
 \nHaworthias make perfect houseplants, they are easy to grow require little care and look absolutely beautiful, there's a Haworthia for any windowsill in the house.
 \n
 \nThey come in many different shapes and colours which are just packed full of amazing detail. They tend to flower annually with a tall slender stem with tiny little white bell shaped flowers.
 \n
 \nHow to care for Haworthia's.
 \n
 \nPlant in free draining compost mix with a top layer of grit or pea gravel. They can be grown in full sun part shade or even just a bright windowsill, we find that for best light levels for growing Haworthias is morning or late afternoon sun in the summer months and full sun in the winter, even grown behind a net curtain in the summer creates a perfect growing environment. A slightly opened window also creates airflow which helps aid root development.
 \n
 \nWater when soil is dry during the summer and less water in the winter. Haworthias can be fed during the growing season every 7-10 days with a liquid seaweed feed.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: x Sedeveria 'Blue Elf'
Short description: x Sedeveria 'Blue Elf' is a cracking little hybrid, it produces multiple offsets as it grows, each glaucous leaf is light blue in colour covered in a white powdery farina, on the very tips of the leaves is this tiny little red dot which looks delightfully attractive.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Rothart'
Short description: Sempervivum 'Rothart' is a very attractive tight clustering variety, its initial offsets tend to appear green contrasting beautifully with the purple colouring of the central rosette, these will eventually take on the same appearance to create a stunning little plant. The webbing helps protect the succulent against cold temperatures and high intense light levels, it can also catch the mist of a cloud passing through a mountainous habitat. \n \nSempervivums come in a fantastic array of colours, forms and textures. They make outstanding garden plants either planted straight out into a rockery or simply planted in pots outside all year round. To achieve the colours these beautiful alpine succulents possess they must receive a minimum of 6 hours full sun a day (more sun more intense colour) during the Spring and Summer. \n \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C and even lower in some cases. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, we recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply re-pot with a slow release fertiliser feed mixed into a gritty compost mix, this will encourage the Sempervivums to have many new offsets and to put on a magnificent flowering display ideal for nectar loving insects.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Anacampseros telephiastrum variegata
Short description:
Anacampseros telephiastrum variegata is an interesting succulent that has amazingly beautiful little pink flowers in early summer which open on sunny days. The leaves are obovate in shape giving these plants a very distinct appearance.
 \n
 \nAs new growth appears it tends to be yellowy green in colour turning to a pink blush as the light levels intensify, the flowers appear from the centre of each rosette enticing it to offset from the base, the stems on the plant have fine white hairs as you can see in the pictures.
 \n
 \nThe species are native to South Africa and can be found growing in rock crevices, as they mature they produce a caudex (a natural reservoir) to store water which helps them survive extreme drought conditions.
 \n
 \nThey make stunning houseplants with its array of chameleon-like colouring and unique form.
Hardiness: Green, Multicoloured, Pink, Red, Variegated, Yellow
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Haworthia 'Manda's'
Short description:
Haworthia 'Manda's' is a strong sturdy form of Haworthia. This plant boasts a star-shaped rosette form with chocolaty-orange leaf colouring in bright light. As it grows offsets will appear from the base.
 \n
 \nThis variety can be grown in high or low light conditions making them ideal houseplants. Allow soil to dry between waterings.
 \n
 \nPot up with a gritty compost mix with a top layer of grit or gravel to aid drainage around the base of the plant.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Gasteria cv. 'Sakura Fuji'
Short description:
The variegated Gasteria cv. 'Sakura Fuji' is extremely slow to propagate but definitely worth the wait, we have had this variety in our collection for well over 10 years till its release in summer 2020.
 \n
 \nIt is a Japanese cultivar of Gasteria with beautiful creamy white leaves and splashes of pink and green throughout giving it a marbled appearance, they grow in a very compact form offsetting very slowly.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade, Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Pot, Rockery, Windowsill

Name: Crassula afra f. variagata
Short description:
This very interesting succulent Crassula afra f. variagata or more commonly known as the elephant bush. This variety is used extensively as a succulent shrub in California due to the size it grows to, a size of 2 to 3 feet in height and a spread of up to 10 feet in ideal conditions. Landscapers love to use it as it creates amazing ground cover that suppresses weeds and survives extremely hot and dry conditions.
 \n
 \nIt's an incredibly easy plant to grow, especially indoors, as they respond well to little care, to keep them compact keep them in a small pot and prune once a year, protect from frosts.
 \n
 \nSometimes seen listed as Portulacaria afra f. variegata.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

A slightly opened window also creates airflow which helps aid root development.

 \nWater when soil is dry during the summer and less water in the winter. Haworthias can be fed during the growing season every 7-10 days with a liquid seaweed feed.

Name: Euphorbia horrida
Short description:
Euphorbia horrida is a species from South Africa, it produces these lovely marbled markings on its leaves, the outer ridges of the leaves have clusters of spines running all the way up and down. The make delightful pot plant specimens, they need good drainage plenty of sun and water during the summer months.
 \n
 \nSeed grown.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Sunset Peony'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Sunset Peony' is a very rare variegated Echeveria, it produces these lovely glaucous leaves, each leaf has green centres with two delicious strips of yellow running down each side. In good light, the outer leaf margins pick up a super stunning red tinge. Altogether, this plant looks and is beautiful.
 \n
 \nWe have found it to be a strong grower and it will offset in time, it makes the most beautiful specimen plant.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: x Semponium 'Sienna'
Short description:
Available in 2021 during the week of the prestigious Chelsea flower show.
 \n
 \nIntroducing the outstandingly beautiful�intergeneric hybrid��Semponium �Sienna�, worlds first official cross between Sempervivum and Aeonium.
 \n
 \nIn a quest to produce hardier succulents for the UK�climate, we have raised a new hybrid between�Sempervivum �Green ice� (raised by Howard Wills and�registered 2006, of unknown parentage) and Aeonium��Ice Warrior� (Aeonium smithii � Aeonium �Cyclops�) Surreal Succulents cultivar.�Using these two plants as the parents should�potentially produce a hardier, more robust and�beautiful succulent as sempervivums are known to be�particularly hardy.
 \n
 \nThe parents are both members of the Crassulaceae�family. However, their flowering seasons are very far�apart, with aeoniums generally flowering in the spring,�and sempervivums flowering from summer to�autumn. That was the real challenge in creating this�hybrid, not to mention the fact that Aeonium flower�very sporadically, so it was incredibly unpredictable.�We were lucky enough to have one of our Aeoniums�start to flower in late summer so we were able to use�fresh pollen from it to cross it with the flowering�Sempervivum �Green Ice�, which in due course�produced seed.
 \n
 \nWe were amazed when we had successfully germinated�the seeds, and we were astonished once we began to see�the first batch of seedlings growing in the seed tray.
 \n
 \n�Semponium �Sienna�
 \n
 \nParentage: Aeonium �Ice Warrior� (m) � Sempervivum��Green Ice� (f).�Etymology: �Semponium �Sienna� is named after Mark�s�first-ever child and daughter who is now 1 year�old.�This brand new hybrid �Semponium �Sienna� is a�prolific grower with a large central rosette which�produces multiple offsets. The leaves are slender with�the outer part of the foliage becoming more spoon-shaped. The colouring is the most exciting part of the�plant with its unusual sienna colour, and its bright red�leaf margins. These plants are now undergoing�hardiness testing to see if they are as hardy as their�Sempervivum parent. The eventual size is 30cm high�and 30cm across.
 \n
 \nWe where due to release�this plant for�the first time at the RHS�Chelsea Flower Show 2020.�We had also entered it�into the Chelsea Plant�of the Year competition�at this show.
 \n
 \nIt will be�on sale here on the website�for the first time in May 2021 and at the same time will be available to purchase at the 2021 Chelsea flower show,�we hope to see you there.

Name: x Graptosedum 'Ghosty'
Short description: Graptoveria 'Ghosty' has fantastic pale leaves on a rosette that will grow to 10-15cm diameter and offset.

Name: Echeveria gibbiflora
Short description:
Echeveria gibbiflora�is a beautiful species from Mexico that can grow to a very good size if given the space to do so.
 \n
 \nIt's an exciting Echeveria to grow as it changes colour from an attractive blue, to a purple and then finally in strong light turns to this bright coral colouring.
 \n
 \nAs it grows it drops its lower leaves revealing this attractive thick stem allowing for under-planting with other low growing varieties such as Echeveria elegans or a mixture of sempervivums.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Duchess of Nuremberg'
Short description: On offer is this popular hybrid Echeveria 'Duchess of Nuremberg', which has stunning purple-blue leaves. It grows to around 15-20cm across and its colour intensifies in strong light.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: x Graptoveria 'Mrs Richards'
Short description: Graptoveria 'Mrs Richards' is a stunning cross of Graptopetalum and Echeveria. It has very attractive purple plump foliage and will offset slowly.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Short description: A lovely 2016 hybrid with delicate glaucous leaves with shades of reds and yellows in full sun.

Name: Echeveria 'Jack Fitzgerald'
Short description:
Echeveria �Jack Fitzgerald� Has striking light green leaves with distinctly attractive red tips. In time it forms multiple rosettes, it works really well planted with other Echeveria and crassulas.
 \n
 \nEcheveria�s are know as summer growers, which means they enjoy feed and water during the warmer months. Check out our how to care for succulents guide for more details.
 \n
 \n
Planting Location: Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: x Cremneria 'Expatriata'
Short description: Cremneria 'Expatriata' is a hybrid of Cremnophila linguifolia and Echeveria amoena 'Microcalyx'. It's colour ranges from light purple through to pale blue depending on the time of year, featuring red tips and leaf margins. A miniature form yet will clump to fill any pot/space. Offsets readily from the base.

This specimen was grown in a 1 litre/13cm pot.
 \n

Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aloe striata (Coral Aloe)
Short description:
One of the most attractive Aloe species around. The Aloe striata commonly know as the coral Aloe is a single rosette-forming succulent.
 \n
 \nIt grows incredibly well in a dry, warm environment like a conservatory, also loves being outdoors during the summer months. Once mature, it produces striking orange flowers.
 \n
 \nThis species will make a perfect standalone plant. Seed-grown at the nursery.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium gorgoneum
Short description:
Aeonium gorgoneum is a species that is rarely found in cultivation. It is not like most Aeoniums as it is not from the Canary Islands, instead in grows in the more tropical Cape Verde Islands. It has attractive light green-yellow leaves that take on a pink tinge in strong light levels.
 \n
 \nOffsets occasionally.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Sedum pachyclados
Short description:
Sedum pachycladus, also known as the Rhodiola pachyclados, is a hardy and beautiful species native to Pakistan and Afghanistan.
 \n
 \nThis succulent features curly leaves that form a carpet of pale-green/blue rosettes. Will bloom every summer in July/August with white flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect in a garden/rockery, to cover a space under taller plants.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Echeveria peacockii

Echeveria peacockii is a fantastic and sought after species with pointed leaves of powdery blue colouring.
 \n

 \n

Name: Delosperma 'Ruby'

Great colours and a great name, lovely cultivar.

 \nSempervivums are among some of the toughest plants within the world of succulents, not only are they extremely hardy (-15�C) but they can survive in drought-like conditions making them one of the best succulents for U.K gardens.

Name: Sedum 'Crocodile'
Short description: Sedum �Crocodile� has beautiful waxy bright green plump leaves that turn red in high light levels. This versatile succulent will offset quickly and fill an outdoor planter very nicely. Makes a lovely companion plant to Echeverias. As the succulent ages it it takes on a reptilian texture to the leaves, great fun and easy to grow.

Short description: Graptoveria 'Fred Ives' is a pretty cross between Graptopetalum paraguayense and Echeveria gibbiflora.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Dorothy'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Dorothy' is a stunning frilly hybrid with bright lush lime leaves outlined with beautiful red margins.
 \nIts a very quick grower and grows very nicely on a bright sunny windowsill.
 \nIntroduced Autumn 2017.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aloe arborescens
Short description:
Aloe arborecens is a wonderful species of Aloe. They can grow to a large clumping size outdoors in the UK. Plant close to a south-facing wall with a good free draining mix.
 \n
 \nAloe arborecens�is native to the Eastern side of South Africa and other countries such as Mozambique and Zimbabwe.
 \n
 \nOnce established they produce these beautiful orange flowers around Christmas time.
 \n
 \nHardy down to -3�C. Protect from extreme weather like the beast from the east. Use a high quality graded fleece.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Voodoo' (L)
Short description: The plant you will receive is the same size or bigger than the plant in the picture which measures: \n \nDiameter - 20cm \n \nHeight - 20cm \n \nA dark name for a really dark-coloured U.S. hybrid Aeonium with has stunning large rosettes on a medium-sized branching cultivar.
Categories: Aeonium > Aeonium U-Z, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Surreal Specials
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Senecio haworthii
Short description:
Senecio haworthii is a very rewarding succulent to grow. Each leaf feels like it is neatly coiled up with fine woolly cotton, giving it its common name of the woolly Senecio.
 \n
 \nThe fine white cocoon-like fibres that coat the leaves act as a natural sunscreen to protect them from the hot sun. They also encourage morning dew to collect on the leaves giving the plant a lifeline to water in its natural habitat in South Africa.
 \n
 \nThey are easy to grow succulents and add a wonderfully unique colour and texture to a succulent display. Kids adore them.
Planting Location: Branching, Spreading
Colour: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: x Pachyveria 'Kobayashi'
Short description: A really great pachyveria with attractive silver colouration and a lovely form with slender pointed leaves.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Deep Purple'
Short description: Aeonium 'Deep Purple' in particular is one of few Aeoniums that actually resembles a purple coloured rosette. Brought out by summer sun, it is a truly wonderful specimen. This fast growing hybrid also throws off large curly leaves similar to Aeonium 'Pomegranate'. \n \nAs shown in the final pictures, it can grow to astonishing heights. Our tallest specimen has reached a height of 85cm from the pot, with a rosette diameter of 40cm. We still believe it can grow taller. \n \nIt tends to offset from bare stem and keep the main rosette in perfect form. Even offsetting from the base.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Darley Blush'
Short description: 2019 introduction \n \nAeonium 'Darley�Blush' is a sensational hybrid with delightful colourings and growth form, it produces a few offsets but stays quite compact. \n \nWe have found that it grows very quickly and makes a fantastic potted succulent either on its own or planted amongst other succulents. \n \nOverall it's a very attractive Aeonium with distinct colouring�with a lovely velvety texture.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Sempervivum calcareum
Short description: Sempervivum calcareum is a popular species of these hardy succulents. It has green leaves with attractive reddish purple tips and will offset freely.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'NASA'
Short description:
Summer 2020 addition.
 \n
 \nThe eye-catching Echeveria 'NASA' has these large reddy/orange coloured leaves that almost look like they could receive a signal from outer space. This delightful Echeveria variety can grow quickly to a good size of approximately 45cm high and 40cm across.
 \n
 \nIt holds beautiful form and colour throughout the year but the colouring is defiantly more intense during the Spring and Summer months.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Lilac Time'
Short description: Sempervivum 'Lilac Time' produces this deep lilac colouring in strong light, the leaf formation is very open with each leaf tampering to a final point which is incredibly symmetrical producing a delightful plant for any situation. The offsets are generated on long side-shoots but quickly develop in to stunning clones of there mother. \n \nSempervivums come in a fantastic array of colours, forms and textures. They make outstanding garden plants either planted straight out into a rockery or simply planted in pots outside all year round. To achieve the colours these beautiful alpine succulents possess they must receive a minimum of 6 hours full sun a day (more sun more intense colour) during the Spring and Summer. \n \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C and even lower in some cases. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, we recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply re-pot with a slow release fertiliser feed mixed into a gritty compost mix, this will encourage the Sempervivums to have many new offsets and to put on a magnificent flowering display ideal for nectar loving insects.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Golden Dial'
Short description: \n \n  \n \nSempervivums come in a fantastic array of colours, forms and textures. They make outstanding garden plants either planted straight out into a rockery or simply planted in pots outside all year round. To achieve the colours these beautiful alpine succulents possess they must receive a minimum of 6 hours full sun a day (more sun more intense colour) during the Spring and Summer. \n \nThey are incredibly hardy, surviving temperatures down to -15�C and even lower in some cases. We find that during the spring they are very hungry plants, we recommend to feed them once every two weeks with a liquid seaweed dilution or simply re-pot with a slow release fertiliser feed mixed into a gritty compost mix, this will encourage the Sempervivums to have many new offsets and to put on a magnificent flowering display ideal for nectar loving insects.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sedum 'Lime Zinger'
Short description:
Sedum 'Lime Zinger' �is a fun and interesting variety with its disked�shaped lime green leaves inching out on long stems, mid to late summer it produces stunning bright purple flowers which are ideal for nectar lovers such as bees and butterflies.
 \n
 \nThis variety of Sedum tends to die back in the winter, but with a little feed as the new leaves are developing in early Spring will entice a much stronger and bigger plant the next season.
 \n
 \nFully hardy in the UK.
 \n
 \nThe cascading form of this sedum makes it an ideal container plant and a perfect accompany to a taller succulent such as Aeonium 'Schwarzkopf'.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Pachyphytum bracteosum
Short description: With rosettes that look look chalky stones, the Pachyphytum bracteosum can grow up to 20cm diameter or more, producing large fleshy leaves and offsets.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Blood' (L)
Short description:
The plant you receive was grown in a 1 litre (13cm) pot.
 \n
 \nAeonium 'Blood' is our very own hybrid. Shown for the first time in our gold medal-winning exhibit at RHS Hampton Court in July 2019. This stunning quick-growing variety is a cross between Aeonium 'Maximus' and Aeonium 'Voodoo'.
 \n
 \nThe early spring sunshine brings out this dazzling rich blood-like colouring in its rosettes which later darken in the summer, as the light levels intensify the leaves turn a deep dark red. We have found it to be an incredibly fast-growing Aeonium just like its parentage. It will produce layers of rosettes at intervals as it grows to create this tree-like form in as little as three years.
 \n
 \nFor best results when growing Aeoniums pot on or feed in early spring. If a plant is well-rooted and established in a pot feed with a 3 or 6-month slow-release fertiliser. It is important that Aeoniums have a good root system before adding any new fertiliser to the soil or compost. If the plants don't anchor down in search for new nutrients then they can become top-heavy and become unstable in a pot or planter.
Planting Location: Red Zone

Name: Aeonium 'Pygmeae' (L)
Short description:
The plant you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm).
 \n
 \nThis U.S. hybrid is a branching, dark leaved Aeonium that, as its name suggests, remains quite small in size.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Echeveria 'Topsy Turvy' (L)
Short description: The plant you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm).\n\nEcheveria 'Topsy Turvy' has a bizarre curled leaf form that makes it a really nice specimen. A truly surreal succulent!
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Crassula tetragona (L)
Short description: Also known as the Miniature Pine Tree, this really structural Crassula has a naturally branching form and a fantastic leaf structure. Reminiscent of a menorah.
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium x loartei (L)
Short description: A lovely compact hybrid with fantastic green rosettes with strong red markings. It is a hybrid of Aeonium sedifolium and Aeonium spathulatum and has the best qualities of both. Also found named as Aeonium arnoldii.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium arboreum v. magnificum (L)
Short description: Aeonium arboreum var. magnificum is an attractive lime-green variety. With it's large leaves and flat rosettes it tends to offset often. Once mature it has a fantastic bright-yellow flower head.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Cotyledon ladismithiensis variegata
Short description:
Cotyledon ladismithiensis variegata (syn. Cotyledon tomentosa subs. ladismithiensis f. variegata), also known as the variegated Bear Paws succulent is a clumping, tall-growing species from Mexico.
 \n
 \nThis plant features pink bell-shaped flowers in summer-late summer. The leaves are a perfect example of the name, they are shaped like Bear's Paws of a size around 2 inches and are thick and fleshy.
 \n
 \nPerfect in a pot on your windowsill or outside in a hanging basket.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sedum dasyphyllum 'Minor'
Short description:
Sedum dasyphyllum 'Minor', also known as Corsican stonecrop, is a delicate but delightfully little Sedum that naturally creeps and cascades through rockeries. It features multiple tiny rosettes of purple, blue and green. Will flower every year.
 \n
 \nMakes the perfect carpet to go under your larger, taller varieties.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Gasteria 'Little Warty'
Short description: Gasteria 'Little Warty' makes a perfect houseplant, it has the most fascinating structural form with stunning leaf markings and a rough almost coarse texture. During the spring, they produce the most beautiful flowering display, featuring a tall slender flower spike boasting balloon-shaped orangey/yellow flowers.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Gasteria vlokii
Short description:
Native to South Africa Gasteria vlokii grows in a low growing form, as the leaves elongate, they tend to fold downwards towards the ground. In early spring they produce a tall pink flower spike boasting a delight of multiple pink green flowers. The leaves of the Gasteria vlokii have hundreds of tiny white specs dotted all over, the texture is rough but pleasant to touch.
 \n
 \nWe grow ours in quite high light levels giving the plant this orange hue, but they can be grown in lower light such as an east or west-facing windowsill. If grown in lower light the leaves grow larger and greener but hold onto the white dots.
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Echeveria 'Gold'
Short description:
This is one of our most exciting cultivars released in the summer of 2020, this cross between Echeveria 'Orion' x Echeveria cuspidata zaragoza is absolutely jaw-droppingly beautiful.

Echeveria 'Gold' has the most unique colourings and markings as it ages, the golden hue just draws you in and as you move in closer you can see this stunning marbling effect throughout, but if it couldn't get any better the whole succulent is covered in a fine dusting of farina all set off by the most amazing glowing red tips.

The 3rd picture is of a baby that has been growing in a low nutrient compost for 6 months, it's just a perfect piece of treasure and a must for any collection.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Candy Crush'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Candy Crush' is an absolutely magical cultivar, a seedling of Echeveria 'Desert Harmony' but unlike it's parentage it has a much pinker paler appearance when grown in high light levels, once large its a majestic looking plant that looks great either on its own or accompanied with other succulents or alpines.
 \n
 \nPicture number 3 shows the mother plant growing in slightly lower light levels and extra feed, you can really see how this plant changes colour in different conditions.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Gasteria bicolor var. liliputana
Short description:
Gasteria bicolor var liliputana is a delightful little plant that produces the most stunning flower display. It grows as a short, compact form but clusters into multiple offsets, all capable of producing their own tall flower stems. Boasting bell-shaped pinky/yellow flowers. Some of our older specimens have had well over 15 flower spikes at once creating an eye-catching display.
 \n
 \nGasteria bicolor var liliputana is a very attractive plant with dark green leaves and flecks of white, to touch it has an interesting tactile texture.
 \n
 \nGasterias are native to South Africa and tend to be tough and rigid plants that are built to survive harsh environments, it is seen as rare in its natural environment but not endangered.
 \n
 \nThey make perfect houseplants because they're incredibly robust and can survive on most windowsills in a house, a west-facing windowsill is ideal as the sun sets it shines through the flowers and stem which sets it all off, this just looks amazing.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Windowsill

Name: Haworthia zebrina
Short description:
Haworthia zebrina, native to South Africa, is a beautiful species that can thrive in low light conditions. By low light, we mean out of direct sunlight on a north-facing windowsill but still receiving natural light.
 \n
 \nThe attractive long slender leaves give the plants an architectural look that looks stunning in the right environment either on a light windowsill in a bathroom or kitchen. Haworthias are incredibly robust and easy to grow, making them some of the best houseplants on the planet.
 \n
 \nOur plants have been growing in high light levels giving the plant a tighter form, in less light the leaves open up and the leaves become a darker green without the reddish tips.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade, Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Pot, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria glauca 'Silver Lining' (L)
Short description: This plant was grown in a 1 litre (13cm) pot. \n \nOften mistaken as Echeveria 'Imbricata' this Echeveria glauca 'Silver Lining' is a definite must for any collection. \n \nAs the plant ages, it produces the most stunning tight-forming blue rosettes with fine red tips on the ends of each leaf. \n \nWe love to use this succulent on mass planted underneath our tall branching Aeoniums in our RHS show gardens. With it being a cultivar of Echeveria glauca, we have found it to be a vigorous grower. It can survive colder and wetter conditions more so than other Echeverias. \n \nIt looks terrific either potted on its own or in a mixed succulent container.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

Name: Terracotta Succulent Bowl
Short description:
Get the Surreal Succulents-look at home with this rustic handmade terracotta succulent bowl. Designed by the award-winning Surreal Succulents very own Mark Lea, you can get the perfect gift for your friends and family or just treat yourself. These terracotta pots are handmade by a local potter John Swan here in Cornwall. Mark has selected the perfect selection of succulents that are hardy and colourful with interesting textures suitable for outside or indoors. \n \nThese planted succulent bowls can be kept outside for the summer and will take a light frost, with this in mind these bowls are the perfect size to bring inside to be enjoyed over the winter on your windowsill. \n \nThe succulents included will fill out nicely over the next 12 to 18 months to give you a rewarding display of potted succulents. \n \nYou will receive the bowl, plants, soil and grit from pictures three, four and five. \n \nPicture one and two is a mature example of a planted bowl after 12 to 18 months. \n \nSucculent bowl kit includes - \n
    \n
  • Handmade terracotta bowl from Cornwall 18cm wide x 8.5 cm (size may vary due to being handmade)
    • \n
  • Succulent soil mix
    • \n
  • Cornish grit top dress
    • \n
  • 1x Echeveria �Duchess of Nuremberg�
    • \n
  • 1x Aloe aristata
    • \n
  • 1x X Sedeveria �Letizia�
    • \n
  • 1x Sempervivum calcareum
    • \n
  • 1x Echeveria elegans
    • \n
\nBuilding your succulent bowl - \n
    \n
  1. Simply add your succulent soil mix
    2. \n
  2. Plant your succulents and spread the Cornish grit top dress around them as you go.
    3. \n
  3. Once you have finished, thoroughly water with the three D�s method - Drench, Drain and Dry.
    4. \n
  4. Let your bowl dry and repeat the watering process.
    5. \n
\nFor more information about keeping succulents, check out our care guide.

Name: Echeveria 'White Star'
Short description:
Echeveria 'White Star' is a truly glorious cultivar of unknown parentage.
 \n
 \nThis specimen has the most amazing beautiful leaf shape and formation. �The leaves are full of delicate shades of pastel blue/purple colourings which are highlighted by the white glow of the leaf margins.
 \n
 \nPerfect to add a bright colour to your succulent collection, great on a windowsill or conservatory.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Misty'
Short description:
2020 introduction.
 \n
 \nEcheveria 'Misty' is a delightful star-shaped form of Echeveria with its pastel blue/purple colourings and misty like appearance makes a true delight in any collection.
 \n
 \nThe leaves are delicately covered in a dusting of farina which looks so appealing to touch but must be resisted as the farina protects the plant against the strong summer sun acting as a natural sunscreen.
 \n
 \nWhere possible, watering from underneath is always recommended on plants with farina.
 \n
 \n 
 \n
 \nParentage Unknown.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium urbicum v. meriodonalis
Short description: Aeonium urbicum var. meriodonalis is rarely found in cultivation. They can grow up to 2m high so make a dramatic specimen plant, especially when it's whitish-green cone-shaped flower is in full bloom. Seed grown.
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall

Name: Echeveria 'Blue Curls'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Blue Curls' is a frilly hybrid from North America. Like a lot of frilly Echeveria, this one just doesn't stop growing and can reach over 15 inches in diameter.
 \n
 \nThe leaves feature so many colours throughout the year, the primary colour is blue, outer leaf margin being a stunning pale-green that turns purple/pink once mature.
 \n
 \nWould look perfect as a bowl feature or standalone in a pot.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria goldmanii
Short description: This species, discovered in Mexico, is a small-headed offsetter. It is one of a few bushier Echeverias, making it a must for any collection! \n \nEcheveria goldmanii features a main rosette that grows tall and similar to Crassula ovata, offsetting and branching, which is very unusual. The leaves are coloured green which can go gold under strong light levels and a distinctive red stripe around the leaf margins. During mid too late spring it produces multiple stems of tall flower stems all boasting these beautiful pink flowers. \n \nRecommended in a pot or on your windowsill.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Lily Pad'
Short description:
This unusual variety gets its name from it's thick, deep-green leaves. It features a sticky yet glossy texture that it inherits from its suggested parentage of Aeonium lindleyi x Aeonium nobile.
 \n
 \nIf left to grow naturally, the main rosette can reach a size of 6 inches but will offset readily. Once mature, after a few years, it will create a dome-like shape. Also features the most amazing golden orange flowers.
 \n
 \nWould look perfect as a small feature in a rockery, or in a pot outside on a garden table.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria bradburiana
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Sempervivum 'Dyke'
Short description:
Sempervivum 'Dyke' is a very dark, attractive variety. It features a dome-shaped rosette followed by branched offsets meaning the main rosette stays intact.
 \n
 \nEasily propagated by offset and a real stunner. Can be added to your succulent display as a contrast in colour and texture.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Jovibarba heuffelii 'Mystique'
Short description:
Jovibarba heuffelii 'Mystique' has impressive rich-red foliage edged with these fine white hairs along the leaf margins. The Jovibarba will grow into a tight, clustering form that would look great planted in a succulent bowl and placed as a centrepiece in an outside dining area.
 \n
 \nThe stemless alpine species of Jovibarba are closely related to Sempervivum requiring almost identical growing conditions, the leaves of the Jovibarba tend to be more rigid to touch making them tougher and less likely to break under force. Incredibly drought and frost resistant that requires little care but rewards you with absolute beauty.
 \n
 \nPot on in the spring and add slow-release feeding granules to the succulent mix to encourage good strong growth through the season.
 \n
 \nTop dress with a thin layer of grit or gravel to mimic its natural Alpine environment.
 \n
 \nJovibarba are a close family member of Sempervivum, the differences are that they produce their pups from the stems or amongst the leaves and will a lot of the time, roll away from the mother. Whereas the Sempervivum will always offset using stolons. They also have bell-shaped flowers rather than the Sempervivum star-shaped flowers.
Planting Location: Green Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Blue Waves' (L)
Short description: The specimen you receive was grown in a 1 litre (13cm) pot. \n \nEcheveria 'Blue Waves' has striking wavy leaf edges, great colours and grows to around 25cm across. It is a Frank Reinelt hybrid, a sister seedling of E. 'Blue Curls'. Once the Echeveria 'Blue Waves' is mature enough, it can put on this dazzling summer display with up to 5 magnificent flower spikes at once. \n \nThis succulent produces multiple offsets as it grows, to encourage more offsets pot on in mid-spring with a slow-release granular feed added to the compost. \n \nThe frilly varieties of Echeveria make perfect pot plants especially if given the space to grow and show off their unusual foliage.
Categories: Echeveria > Echeveria A-J, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: x Graptoveria 'Fred Ives' (XL)
Short description:
The plant you receive was grown in a 4L pot and is branching with multiple offsets.
 \n
 \nGraptoveria 'Fred Ives' is a pretty cross between Graptopetalum paraguayense and Echeveria gibbiflora.
Categories: Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Others, Surreal Specials
Light Aspect: Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Blondie' (L)
Short description: The plant you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm). \n \nEcheveria 'Blondie' is a fast-growing, frilly succulent. It is a pale green colour with large fleshy leaves. Will feature red tips under stress of high light levels. \n \nIts unique pale colouring looks excellent as part of a collection. This hybrid works better as a large standalone specimen.
Categories: Echeveria > Echeveria A-J, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Red Zone
Colour: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Matrix' (L)
Short description: The plant you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm). \n \nEcheveria 'Matrix' is our own exciting frilly hybrid, previewed for the first time in our RHS Gold winning garden at Hampton Court in 2019. \n \nA fast grower which produces these intense deep-red colours that last all year round. This hybrid can grow to the size of a basketball if given the space. \n \nEcheveria 'Matrix' would make the perfect potted succulent for your patio in the summer months and great as a stand-alone specimen in any collection.
Categories: Echeveria > Echeveria K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: Echeveria 'NASA' (L)
Short description: The specimen you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm). \n \nSummer 2020 addition. \n \nThe eye-catching Echeveria 'NASA' has these large reddy/orange coloured leaves that almost look like they could receive a signal from outer space. This delightful Echeveria variety can grow quickly to a good size of approximately 45cm high and 40cm across. \n \nIt holds beautiful form and colour throughout the year but the colouring is defiantly more intense during the Spring and Summer months.
Categories: Echeveria > Echeveria K-N, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Princess Lace' (L)
Short description: The specimen you receive was grown in a 1litre pot (13cm). \n \nWhat a delicious looking frilly succulent Echeveria 'Princess Lace' is. It has these large wavy, multicoloured leaves with a hint of lemon green and salmon pink, turning to a vibrant blue as it ages. \n \nOne rosette can grow to an outstanding size of over 30cm, they produce a tall flower stem boasting large flowers in mid-summer which are high in nectar, producing a delicious feed for any passing bee.
Categories: Echeveria > Echeveria O-Z, Surreal Specials > Large Specimens
Planting Location: Amber Zone

Name: x Pachyveria 'Ursa Major' (L)

Name: Echeveria 'Arlie Wright'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Arlie Wright', created and named after Dick Wright's mother in 1964, is a stunning frilly Echeveria with stunning colours all year round.
 \n
 \nIf grown in the correct conditions, this plant can grow to astonishing sizes and display an out of this world array of colours. The rosette keeps a very compact and strong form. This hybrid flowers during the spring and shoots beautiful orangey-yellow flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect as a standalone feature plant or to add contrast to your collection.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Fiesta'
Short description:
Aeonium 'Fiesta' is one of the most outstanding variegated cultivars in the Aeonium world. The variegation is spectacular, changing colour throughout the growing season. Each rosette can grow up to 8'' in diameter and looks beautiful potted up on its own as a feature plant.

\nAs the succulent grows it tends to branch, to encourage more branches pot on during the spring by lowering the main growing stem into the succulent compost to encourage new roots to feed the plant. \n

When growing the variegated varieties it is advised to protect them from direct sunlight. We recommend to position them under other plants such as palms or taller Aeoniums. You can also place them in a position where they get morning or afternoon sun. A perfect succulent for a semi-shady balcony or patio.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Growth Form: Conservatory, Dry Shade, Pot, Rockery, Windowsill

Short description: x Graptoveria 'Pearl Dazzler' is a 2020 hybrid. \n \nSuggested by the name, this variety features a pearlescent colouring of different shades of pink. Similar to x Graptoveria 'Douglas Huth' but is a� faster grower, going a deeper purple in strong light. \n \nPerfect for adding colour to your succulent collection or as a starter succulent as it is so easy to grow.

Short description:
x Pachyveria 'Empress', created by Dave Poulgrain, is a hybrid of x Pachyveria 'Myrtilla' and an unknown blue Echeveria (rumoured to be 'Juniper').
 \n
 \nThis plant features elegant large deep-blue leaves that shape to create a large open rosette. It will go almost a completely different colour under strong light, turning from deep-blue to army-green. It will bloom every year with a thick pink stem that contrasts against the plant and shows off its beautiful array of fluorescent flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect indoors on a windowsill or outside in a pot to grow large. It will offset naturally and can grow to a rather large size.

Short description:
A 2020 release. Echeveria 'Holy Gate' is a hybrid of unknown parentage.
 \n
 \nThis plant has beautiful, almost pearlescent colouring during the hotter months and will curl up under strong light to create this colourful rose-bud shaping. A very resilient succulent that grows easily without trouble.
 \n
 \nThe perfect starting succulent due to its toughness and strong will to live. Plant alongside other Echeveria to show off its colours and contrast it against other varieties. Perfect in a pot outdoors or indoors.

Name: Astroloba skinneri
Short description:
Alstroba skinneri is a stunning star-shaped succulent that's rarely available in cultivation, the lime coloured leaves are triangular in shape and strong and rigid to touch. In high light, the older leaves turn a sunset orange colouring which really sets off the lime green centre of the rosette.
 \n
 \nWe have been growing this particular variety for many years and have found it to be incredibly easy to grow, it would definitely be a great succulent for beginners indoors on a bright/sunny windowsill.
 \n
 \nBelieved to be very closely related to Haworthia and sometimes seen listed as x Astroworthia skinneri.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade

As they age they produce a slight pinkish blush, a perfect plant for a cool/cold conservatory or windowsill.

Short description:
Sempervivum 'Lynn's Choice' is a 1972 hybrid bred by Helen E. Payne in the USA.
 \n
 \nIt features unusual mid-tone colours ranging from bronze to green and will change throughout the year. Like other Sempervivums, it is monocarpic but will offset a lot before and whilst flowering, the flowers are pink and attract a lot of happy bees in the late summer.
 \n
 \nPlanted best outdoors, a great carpet plant.
Planting Location: Green Zone

Name: Aloe 'Marco'
Short description:
Aloe 'Marco' is a Proven Winners selected hybrid.
 \n
 \nThis plant features beautiful colouring of sea-blue to green throughout the leaves. Along the leaf margins are some orange teeth and to top it off, there are some white markings all down the leaf.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a windowsill or a shady spot. Will go a lighter green/blue under strong light levels. This hybrid will add great contrast to your succulent bowl.

Sedum oaxacanum is a small-headed species that is native to Mexico.
 \n
 \nThis plant features multiple star-shaped rosettes that flower during the spring. A beautiful species that can be used to carpet your Aeonium collection and fill spaces below other plants.
 \n
 \nRecommended to be outside all year round in the UK and would look perfect in a hanging basket, rockery, wall or pot.

Short description:
Crassula ovata 'Hobbit', also known as ovata monstruosa, is a cultivar of Jade Plant that has curled leaves.
 \n
 \nThis variety blooms once mature with beautiful white flowers and can reach huge sizes, just like the ovata. In some cases, it has reached 3 feet tall and 2 feet wide. It's quite a slow grower so will not need to be moved or potted on too often.
 \n
 \nPerfect for indoors in a light spot and outdoors as a standalone plant or to add texture and contrast to your mixed planter. Ideal for beginners.

Name: Aloe perfoliata
Short description:
Aloe perfoliata, also known as the short-leaved Aloe, is a species from South Africa (Cape).
 \n
 \nThis Aloe species features short green leaves that point upwards as it grows. Aloe perfoliata has green leaves that can turn blue and even pink under high light levels. It is a taller growing Aloe with sharp teeth on each leaf. It is known to cause severe discomfort if consumed, keep away from pets. It blooms in Autumn with small tubular-shaped red flowers.
 \n
 \nA perfect house plant for your indoor windowsill. Would also look great in a rockery.

Name: Agave parrasana 'Fireball'
Short description:
The Agave parrasana �Fireball� has beautiful light blue leaves edged with a golden variegated margin, the Agave on offer is of a very good size and is showing small pups to the side of the mother. As this ornamental Agave grows the leaves fold away from the central growing point leaving behind stunning imprint markings, this combined with the fiery red tips makes this plant a really attractive and collectable plant. The Agave parrasana �Fireball� will grow to a maximum size of 2ft high and a spread of 2ft, as it grows the leaves curve upwards and form the similar shape as an artichoke.
 \nThese agaves are rare to see, and the plant listed is roughly 5 years old.
 \n
 \nYou will receive the plant in the picture, which is growing well in a 1 litre pot, It measures approximately 21cm across and 8cm high. We will ship the Agave out bare root without compost.

Name: Haworthia crispidata f variegata
Short description:
In this lot, we offer the very rare but incredibly desirable variegated form of Haworthia crispidata.
 \nThe Haworthia has very strong and stable creamy white variegation throughout and is ideally suited to a low light environment (out of direct sunlight) which will enhance and help it hold the strong variegation. As you can see in the image it has already started to produce offsets, offsets without green chlorophyll in the leaves will only survive if still attached to the mother plant. Overall this is a unique opportunity to add a truly special plant to your collection.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 7cm pot and measures approx. 7cm across and 5cm high.

Name: Kalanchoe luciae 'Fantastic' variegated Multiheaded
Short description:
This unusually shaped succulent is referred to as the paddle plant for the way the leaves grow. This fantastically sculptural specimen can the perfect plant to use as a centrepiece in a succulent display bowl.
 \nThis plant can give you the most cicadellid patterns in the variegation a making them highly collectable. The Kalanchoe thyrsiflora variegate will apricate good airflow over the winter and will need protection from frost and cold weather.
 \n
 \nThe particular high variegation running throughout the whole plant including the offsets is incredibly strong in fact we have never had one in the collection with this amount of high-end variegation, when the sunlight catches the leaves, they aluminate creating the most truly beautiful display.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 1-litre pot and measures approx. 22cm across and 12cm high.
 \n
 \nWe post all of our plants out bare roots.

Name: Agave potatorum 'Kissho-Kan'
Short description:
Welcome to the auction for this most magnificent specimen of Agave potatorum �Kissho-Kan�. It has been in our collection for over 7 years and is the first plant of this size and stature of this variety we have ever offered. This agave has a truly wonderful compact growing form with strong and stable variegation. As it grows it will produce multiple offsets, each one is a miniature clone of its mother.
 \nAn amazing plant that is easy to grow but must be kept dry during the winter or watered sparingly from below.
 \n
 \nYou will receive the plant in the picture, which is growing well in a 4-litre pot, one of the leaves is slightly damage but this damage will grow out as the plant matures. It measures approximately 20cm across and 13cm high.
 \n
 \nWe post all of our plants out bare roots.

Name: Agave Victoria-reginae var. marginata aurea
Short description:
This slow-growing 5-year-old specimen of Agave Victoria-reginae var. marginata aurea has stable variegation running through the margins of the leaves, as this rare Agave grows small pups will form to produce clones of the mother.
 \nAll forms Agave Victoria-Reginae are highly desirable and collectable, the triangular-shaped leaves with their white striations running throughout make these plants incredibly addictive, but when you add the variegation into the mix it adds an extra element into their beauty.
 \nWhen the agave reaches maturity the form of this plant is just absolutely stunning and would be worthy a winner of any plant competition.
 \n
 \nYou will receive the plant in the picture, which is growing well in a 1-litre pot, It measures approximately 12cm across and 8cm high.
 \n
 \nWe post all of our plants out bare roots.

Name: Agave titanota 'Genryu Kifukurin'
Short description:
On offer is this amazing 12 year old specimen of Agave titanota �Genryu Kifukurin�, a Japanese name meaning yellow ring/edge. These agaves are rarely offered especially of this age or size giving you the unique opportunity to own one of the most collectable forms of Agave titonata in the world.
 \nThe Agave has strong rigid succulent leaves with luscious shape tips, the spines along the leaf margins curve upwards creating a claw-like effect.
 \nThese agaves do produce babies that can be removed and grown on their own to create new specimens.
 \n
 \nYou will receive the plant in the picture, which is growing nicely in a 3-litre pot, the Agave measures approximately 20cm across and 14cm high.
 \n
 \nWe post all of our plants out bare roots.

Name: Tulista marginata
Short description:
The species of Tulista has recently separated away from Haworthia, but much like Haworthias, they are very easy to grow and make amazing houseplants. The Tulista marginata is one of the most striking and structural forms of the species, this rare succulent can often grow as a single rosette.
 \nThe leaves are dotted with white specks along the back of the leaf and along the leaf margins giving the plant a beautiful appearance. This is one of two plants we have in the whole collection.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 1-litre pot and measures approx. 10cm across and 8cm high.

Short description:
If the Echeveria elegans wasn�t beautiful enough this cristated form of this delightful succulent is a must for any collection. This strong grower will throw out the odd original offset as it grows and will form into an amazing specimen overtime. The winter colours of the Echeveria elegans is one of its most attractive features. In cold, dry conditions the coral-blue colouring will become a blush of magenta.
 \n

The plant on offer is growing nicely in a 1-litre pot, the clustering effect of the leaves makes it look like it's been taken straight out of a coral reef. The blue leaves will turn slightly purple, and on the tips of the leaves, they will produce a hint of magenta as light levels intense. As you can see in the images the plant will send out the odd true offset of the original form of this plant, which you can take off and plant up as its own specimen.

Short description:
Welcome to the auction of this magnificent 7-year-old large specimen of Echeveria agavoides �Arrow� cristata. If the Arrow variety wasn�t already attractive enough then this beautiful cristate form will blow you away, a combination of green leaves and the almost black tips on mass just captivates you and lures you in for a closer look. They form without a central growing point allowing them to cluster and form the most amazing looking plant as it ages, the succulent on offer is a really strong and healthy plant that would not look out of place in any collection.

Echeveria agavoides f.cristata
 \nThis stunningly form of Echeveria agavoides f. cristata is on its way of becoming a truly outstanding specimen, its lush green colouring coupled with the hundreds of tightly packed leaves will just get better as it grows. These cristated forms are incredibly collectable, they form without a central growing point allowing them to cluster and form the most amazing looking plant as it ages.

Name: Echeveria purpusorum 'White Form' form 1
Short description:
This is an extremely rare form of Echeveria purpusorum which has white colouration with red outlines. These are so highly collectable as they are extremely hard to come by. It is a strong structural plant with robust leaves and form, a truly choice plant.
 \nIt is a slow grower and to keep the white colouration it will need to be grown hard with a bright light.
 \nThis plant will lose its white colouring in a higher nutrient compost mix, so to keep the strong white colour you can plant it in a 50/50 gritty succulent mix.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 7cm pot and measures approx 4.5cm across and 2cm high.

Name: x Graptoveria 'Nyla'
Short description:
World�s first exclusive.
 \nx Graptoveria �Nyla� is an exclusive Surreal Succulents hybrid.
 \nFinally, the day has come for the long-awaited arrival of the magical x Graptoveria �Nyla�, available here for the first time in the world.
 \nThe first time we ever showed this amazing plant was at the RHS Malvern Spring Show back in 2018, even back then we didn�t offer any to sell because we were showing the only ones on the planet at that point, since then we have managed to produce some more offsets but this plant has been incredibly slow to produce them.
 \n
 \nThe original mother plant came from a seed batch back in 2014 and out of the hundreds of seeds that came up Nyla was the only seedling of this colour, the rest of the seeds were blue, from the same seed batch we also got x Graptoveria �Supernova�.
 \nOver the years we have noticed that not all offsets have this amazing pink colouring in-fact they revert into a blue form which is easier and quicker to grow which we offer online because the offsets sometimes revert we have come to the conclusion that the plant must be an incredibly rare mutant form, much like a variegated plant but this one somehow turned out into this unbelievable pink specimen.
 \nTo get the amazing intense pink colouring, grow x Graptoveria �Nyla� in the morning or late afternoon sun during the summer, as we have noticed strong intense light can affect and wash out the colours.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 9cm pot and measures approx. 6cm across and 4cm high.
 \n
 \nNamed after Succulent Dan�s daughter Nyla.
 \n
 \nWe post all of our plants out bare roots.

Name: Haworthia retusa f variegata (L)
Short description:
The rare and fascinating multicoloured Haworthia retusa f. variegata is a very beautiful and easy succulent to grow, it produces one central dominant rosette, off this one rosette, multiple striking yellow and green coloured unique offsets form.
 \nThe tops of the leaves are translucent which allows sunlight to pass through, as the light reacts with the cells of the plant the light is absorbed and reflected back out in the most dazzling of ways, much like a stain glass window.
 \n
 \nThe offsets can be removed with a sharp sterile knife and potted up as new plants, try and take offsets that are larger than a fifty pence piece for best results of propagation.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive, it�s growing well in a 1-litre pot cm pot and measures approx. 10cm across and 8cm high.
 \n
 \nAll plants are sent bare root.

Name: Echeveria purpusorum 'White Form' form 2
Short description:
This is an extremely rare form of Echeveria purpusorum which has white colouration with red outlines. These are so highly collectable as they are extremely hard to come by. It is a strong structural plant with robust leaves and form, a truly choice plant.
 \nIt is a slow grower and to keep the white colouration it will need to be grown hard with a bright light.
 \nThis plant will lose its white colouring in a higher nutrient compost mix, so to keep the strong white colour you can plant it in a 50/50 gritty succulent mix.
 \n
 \nThe plant in the image is the one you will receive; it�s growing well in a 7cm pot and measures approx 4.5cm across and 2cm high.

Agave potatorum Kissho Kan is an easy to keep slow growing verigated agave potatorum.
 \n

Haworthia cooperi �Black Muscle�
 \n
 \nWhat a wonderful little plant this Hawothia cooperi �Black Muscle� is, the fine delicate translucent leaves have these very attractive striations which almost look like pencil markings, the slightly blue slate colouring to the leaves just draws you in. The most intriguing part of this magical little succulent has to be the pointy shape of the leaves and combined with a low winter sun makes this plant look like a little gemstone sat on a windowsill.

When the early morning or late evening sun shines through the translucent leaves it lights up like a little beacon.

Name: Haworthia cooperii 'White Variegata'
Short description:
Haworthia cooperii �White Variegata�
 \n
 \nEvery collection has to have a least one Haworthia and this variety has to be right at the top of the list. Introducing the truly stunning Haworthia cooperi �White Variegata�, a slow growing succulent with beautiful markings and almost pure white colourings. As it grows the older outside leaves open outwards giving it a star shape appearance. The translucent leaves are sleek and slender and can grow between 3-4cm in length, each leaf ending with a fine hair like tip, as the succulent matures it will form into a clump with multiple babies that can be removed and shared with friends and family.

Name: Haworthia cooperi 'OB1'
Short description:
The incredibly attractive Haworthia cooperi 'OB1' looks like lots of neatly arranged translucent jelly beans, new leaves are produced from the centre of the plant and as they age they produce this pink tinge if grown in good light, the tips of each leaf acts like a little window which allows light to pass in to aid photosynthesis.
 \n
 \nHaworthia's make perfect houseplants, they are easy to grow require little care and look absolutely beautiful, there's a Haworthia for any windowsill in the house.
 \n
 \nThey come in many different shapes and colours which are just packed full of amazing detail. They tend to flower annually with a tall slender stem with tiny little white bell-shaped flowers.
 \n
 \nHow to care for Haworthia's.
 \n
 \nPlant in free draining compost mix with a top layer of grit or pea gravel. They can be grown in full sun part shade or even just a bright windowsill, we find that for best light levels for growing Haworthias is morning or late afternoon sun in the summer months and full sun in the winter, even grown behind a net curtain in the summer creates a perfect growing environment. A slightly opened window also creates airflow which helps aid root development.
 \n
 \nWater when soil is dry during the summer and less water in the winter. Haworthias can be fed during the growing season every 7-10 days with a liquid seaweed feed.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Haworthia
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Haworthia pygmaea 'Snow Sato'

Haworthia pygmaea �Snow Sato�

 \nWhat an absolutely stunning plant the Haworthia pygmaea �Snow Sato� is, it has some of the most warming features of all Hawothias, in fact you could easily be forgiven as acquiring one as a pet. They have the most tactile of leaves and velvety look that you can�t resist to stroke.
 \n
 \nThe triangular leaves have hundreds of fine hairs broken up by these unique fingerprint-like markings running from the centre outwards to the tips, in nature the fine hairs would collect morning due and channel the water down into the plant using these miniature streams.
 \nThey make the best houseplants as they require low light conditions and will be happy to go without water for long periods.
