 \n
 \nThis plant features green with yellow and pink tones throughout the whole plant. Each head grows upwards and creates multiple spiral staircase-like columns, an extremely colourful Sedum.
 \n
 \nVery worthy of a main spot on a windowsill, it would make a perfect houseplant, either hanging or grounded.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Sedum
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Cotyledon orbiculata var. flanaganii f. variegata
Short description:
Cotyledon orbiculata var. flanaganii f. variegata
 \n
 \nThis incredibly rare variegated variety of Cotyledon orbiculata var. flanaganii is native to South Africa. This is a highly collectable popular succulent in Asia and is a centre piece in any collection.
 \n
 \nThis succulent shrub features fingers of silvery-blue and is dotted with yellow variegation, that spiral to grow tall. The leaves have a lipstick-red colouring to make for a perfect contrast when this plant is mature it�s a real showstopper adding hight and a contrast of colour almost like a rainbow in each leaf.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Others
Light Aspect: Green, Multicoloured, Pink, Red, Variegated, Yellow
Planting Location: Branching

Name: x Graptoveria 'Titubans' f. variegata
Short description: x Graptoveria 'Titubans' f. variegata is an intergeneric cross between Graptopetalum paraguayense and Echever�a derenbergii. This is the variegated apricot version. This plant is a fantastic succulent that grows with compact rosettes with colourings of peach yellow and green variegation stripes. This is an attractive, highly collectable plant that can freely offset and form attractive colourful clumps. Works well as a potted succulent display.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Others
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Echeveria runyonii variegata 'Akaihosi'
Short description:
Echeveria runyonii variegata �Akaihosi�, also known as Macedonia, is a variegated form of Echeveria runyonii from Japan.
 \n
 \nAn extremely rare plant. The colour, along with the runyonii silvery-blue, ranges from vanilla to sunset-pink throughout the year and will curl under strong light. Will flower in mid-late spring.
 \n
 \nThis plant would not go unnoticed in any collection, display alongside other variegates and compare the changes in colour throughout the year. Would look great near a �Compton Carousel�.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria 'Rainbow'
Short description:
The amazing Echeveria �Rainbow� is a variegated form of Echeveria �Perle Von N�rnberg�, and is worthy of it�s name.
 \n
 \nEcheveria �Rainbow� changes colour throughout the year, from deep-pinks to all shades of purple but during the summer, the middle goes an almost fluorescent pink, creating an explosion of colour wherever it is displayed. A true collector�s plant.
 \n
 \nDisplay on an east or west facing windowsill to keep a strong variegation, try not to allow midday sun on variegated plants. The perfect indoor plant.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria minima 'Red Edge'
Short description: Echeveria minima �Red Edge� is a red-tipped form of Echeveria minima and is native to Mexico. This is a popular, collectable succulent in Japan and Asia. Like the name minima suggest this is a miniature succulent that grows in a tight clumping formation. This plant is named Red Edge as in stronger light levels or cooler temperatures it has bright red edges. This is an attractive succulent plant when mature with perfect details in a tiny form. Looks great when mature or part of a potted succulent collection.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Crassula deceptor
Short description:
Crassula deceptor
 \nCrassula deceptor is a small species native to South Africa and Namibia.
 \n
 \nIt consists of silvery-white fleshy leaves that form a compact column that stays low and compact. It is a clumping and spreading succulent that offsets readily. In time, the leaves will become pointy and prove to be a real sculptural highlight in any location. It shoots flower stems from the central rosette in winter, consisting of pink, sweet-scented flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect for adding texture and contrasting colour to any succulent display.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Crassula
Planting Location: Clumping

Name: Crassula 'Lucky Star'
Short description:
Crassula �Lucky Star�
 \nCrassula �Lucky Star� is a close relative of Crassula �Baby Necklace�, consisting of the same parentage (Crassula rupestris x Crassula perforata) but seems to have taken more of the perforata form.
 \n
 \nThis hybrid adds the beautiful red blush of the rupestris, along with the thinner leaves, to the size and height of the perforata. Crassula rupestris is quite a dominant species, with a lot of hybrids of the plant looking more like itself rather than the other parent, so a plant like this is a rare find.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Crassula
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Echeveria colorata f. Tapalpa
Short description:
Echeveria colorata f. Tapalpa, Echeveria colorata x Echeveria lindsayana, is a natural hybrid found in the mountains of Tapala of which this plant is named.
 \n
 \nIt has a soft white powdery appearance with bright pink tips in strong sunlight, this plant can look impressive when mature with pink dotty edges. Makes a great standalone succulent plant with its bold appearance.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Haworthia retusa f. variegata
Short description:
Haworthia retusa f. variegata
 \n
 \nThe rare and fascinating multicoloured Haworthia retusa f. variegata is a very beautiful and easy succulent to grow, it produces one central dominant rosette, off this one rosette multiple striking yellow and green coloured unique offset�s form.
 \n
 \nThe tops of the leaves are translucent which allows sunlight to pass through, as the light reacts with the cells of the plant the light is absorbed and reflected back out in the most dazzling of ways, much like a stain glass window.
 \n
 \nThe offsets can be removed with a sharp sterile knife and potted up as new plants, try to take off some of the offsets with the root system still attached.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Haworthia
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria 'White Rose'
Short description:
Echeveria �White Rose� gets its name from its rose-shaped rosette and lotus-style large leaves.
 \n
 \nThis hybrid is a base-white plant, decorated with farina and will feature pink leaf margins under strong light. The tips of the leaves are almost agavoides-pointy and really add to the nature of this stunning plant. This variety blooms in mid-spring with orange and red flowers on tall, thin flower spikes.
 \n
 \nThe perfect feature plant, a real collector�s item.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Oxalis palmifrons
Short description:
Oxalis palmifrons (Palm-leaf False Shamrock).
 \n
 \nOxalis palmifrions is truly one of mother nature�s most beautiful plants, native to south Africa where it�s dormant during the summer and comes to life during the cooler months. This plant is said to look like mini palm trees from above. It has attractive lush green foliage which can turn red/orange and can start to flower as the new growing season starts annually. Oxalis palmifrons is a very slow low growing perennial and can ten years to reach two foot wide.
 \n
 \nThis plant is particularly hardy to -10 but needs to be in a free-draining soil mix over the winter growing season. Can be grown in a dry bright spot in the garden or indoors, make sure not to get the bottom of this plant waterlogged, it will appreciate a good top dress layer.
 \n
 \nIn the summer this plant will disappear into dormancy and draw all its leaves and stems back into the planted bulb.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Others
Planting Location: Spreading

Name: Haworthia 'Inca Rose'
Short description:
The Haworthia �Inca Rose� is a design of true beauty, the markings on the strong vigorous luminous leaves are to die for, each leaf decorated in its own unique pattern much like a fingerprint. As the plant grows the detail just gets more and more interesting and the colours will change with the light levels and the seasons.
 \n
 \nIt�s a beautiful and easy succulent to grow, a great gift and companion for a friend or a student who�s away from home for the first time.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Haworthia
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria 'Compton Carousel'
Short description:
Echeveria �Compton Carousel�
 \n
 \nThis extremely sought-after succulent is a variegated Echeveria secunda var glauca. A clumping succulent that features a beautiful, strong variegation on the blue/grey leaves. Will have hints of pink under stress. Like the Echeveria secunda var glauca, it features circular, pointy leaves on a tight rosette. The flowers are orange and yellow that will appear on a stem that can grow to almost a metre in height.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria tolimanensis
Short description:
Echeveria tolimanensis is a rare species from Mexico, named for its locality in Barranca de Tolim�n.
 \n
 \nThis species is sometimes mistaken as a Pachyphytum due to its larger, fleshy leaves. It consists of a structural and tight rosette with beautiful growth markings on a pale-pink leaf, the leaf tips feature almost agavoides type spikes. Once mature, the lower leaves will grow long and point upwards, making it a very fierce-looking plant. This variety blooms in spring and will throw off an abundance of bell-shaped flowers of pink and yellow colouring.
 \n
 \nA great feature plant, especially when mature.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Echeveria 'Trumso'
Short description:
Echeveria �Trumso� is a hybrid from Korea of unknown parentage although we believe Echeveria laui to be a mother.
 \n
 \nThis stunning plant features the large leaves similar to laui, the extreme amount of white farina coating but with an added raspberry middle, just like a raspberry yoghurt! Probably one of the tastiest looking succulents out there! The red middle will come out under stress, it is truly a rare succulent. Not many feature the colouring and contrast such as this.
 \n
 \nPerfect feature plant, would sit perfectly indoors on a windowsill.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Compact

Name: Dudleya gnoma S.W.McCabe
Short description:
Dudleya gnoma S.W.McCabe is a species native to the Santa Rosa Island in the state of California, discovered in the 1950s.
 \n
 \nThis species features heavy farina on an almost Agave-like rosette, due to the leaves being so pointy. Its colours range from ghost-white to candy-pink and will change throughout the year. Dudleya throw off the most beautiful array of large flowers, usually come in multiples. They consist of pink spikes that form large yellow star-shaped bell flowers.
 \n
 \nPerfect for a windowsill or conservatory.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Others
Planting Location: Branching

Name: x Graptoveria 'Titubans' f. variegata Clusted
Short description:
x Graptoveria 'Titubans' f. variegata is an intergeneric cross between Graptopetalum paraguayense and Echever�a derenbergii. This is the variegated apricot version. This plant is a fantastic succulent that grows with compact rosettes with colourings of peach yellow and green variegation stripes. This is an attractive, highly collectable plant that can freely offset and form attractive colourful clumps. Works well as a potted succulent display.
 \n
 \nThis comes as a larger plant which is already clustered.

Planting Location: Branching

Name: x Graptoveria �Nyla Blue�
Short description:
x Graptoveria �Nyla Blue' is the blue form of the much desired x Graptoveria �Nyla�. They are from the same seed batch as x Graptoveria �Supernova� but are very different.
 \n
 \nCombinations of bright-pink and elegant-blue to create a beautiful
 \ndisplay of gradients similar to some of the most gorgeous sunsets.
 \nEverchanging throughout the year. Not only is it the colour that is
 \nastonishing but the form. Like the x Graptoveria �Supernova� it is a
 \nspiralling plant once mature. We find this plant to be fast growing
 \nunlike the mutant �Nyla� specimen.
 \n
 \nPerfect plant to display in your rare collection."
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Surreal Hybrids
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Haworthia cooperi �Amber�
Short description:
"Haworthia cooperi �Amber�
 \n
 \nThis highly prized and characteristic Haworthia cooperi �Amber� is packed with detail, colour and form. When the Sun aluminates the foliage the translucent leaves erupt into the most incredibly dazzling display and looks just like a living crystal.
 \nAs the lime green leaves develop from the centre of the plant, the fine white mosaic markings slowly separate and spread out as the leaves grow allowing for the crystal-like windows to develop.
 \nAs the outer leaves age, they darken giving the plant an almost variegated appearance.
 \n
 \nAs the Haworthia grows it will produce offsets and in time these offsets can be removed to create new plants to be potted up separately.
 \n
 \nIf you are looking for a houseplant that is compact and easy to grow, then Haworthias have to be top of that list."
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Haworthia, Rare Plant Fair
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Crassula �Fantasy' variegata
Short description:
"Crassula �Fantasy' variegata
 \n
 \nCrassula �Fantasy' variegata is the incredibly rare form of the much-loved trailing plant the Crassula perforata ssp. Kougaensis, which is a highly sort after and popular variety. This is a miniature form of Crassula perforata.
 \n
 \nThis subspecies is a small, trailing succulent that has tough, woody stems allowing it to carry itself and stay in formation. The plant consists of small rosettes that etiolate naturally to create a snake-like sculpture, it displays colours of green and yellow, each stem looks very much like a caterpillar. It blooms in the late spring/summer with beautiful pink flowers that appear from the central rosettes. It will offset readily all year round but mostly during and after flowering."
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Crassula
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Agave victoriae-reginae
Short description:
Also known as the royal Agave, visually stunning and incredibly hardy this popular variety is native to Mexico. Unlike many of its relatives, it only has spines on the very tips of its leaves.
 \n
 \nThe most unique and beautiful feature of this succulent has to be the white stripe running through each of its leaves, and these become more pronounced with age.
 \n
 \nAwarded the RHS Award of Garden Merit for resistance to pests and diseases, grows well in the UK climate.
 \n
 \nLike most Agaves, it is best to keep as dry as possible during the winter months, primarily if being grown outdoor.
 \n
 \nAgave victoriae-reginae can survive temperatures as low as -10�C if kept dry.
Categories: Agave, Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now
Planting Location: Pupping
Growth Form: Conservatory, greenhouse, Patio, Pot, Rockery, Windowsill

Name: Haworthia obtusa �Marin� f. variegata
Short description: The Haworthia Obtusa �Marin� f. variegata are very rare and incredibly special plants, these miniature translucent succulents are highly collectable. The variegation patterns of this plant give it a yin-yang like appearance, a truly choice plant that would look gorgeous in any collection. Slowly over time the Haworthia will offset producing new babies with similar characteristics as the mother
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Haworthia
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Echeveria 'Pinwheel'
Short description: This rare Echeveria 'Pinwheel' is a form of the popular species and is a true delight to grow, it�s tight forming rosettes blushed with a purply/red colouring really draw you in, as the plant ages it freely offsets with into a tight clump of identical captivating rosettes. They work well when planted at the front of a mixed succulent planter where it can be admired as it grows.
Categories: Rare Plant Fair > Buy It Now, Echeveria
Planting Location: Branching

Name: Echeveria 'Raindrops'
Short description:
A fantastic and magical Echeveria that really does live up to its name, it produces these attractive raindrop-like bumps on its leaves.
 \n
 \nTo bring out the beautiful purple, red and blue colourings in the leaves, we suggest you grow this Echeveria in strong light and just admire its truly surreal growth form.

Name: Echeveria 'Decora'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Decora' is the variegated variety of Echeveria gibbiflora 'Metallica', originating from Mexico.
 \n
 \nThis large-leaved variegate is a great looking sculptural plant. It features colours ranging from pink, silver and yellow. Echeveria 'Decora' is extremely unique in colour and form, making it very sought after. This particular variety will bloom in the spring with pink and yellow flowers.
 \n
 \nWould sit as an amazing feature plant along with other rare succulents.
Planting Location: Red Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Patio, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Aeonium 'Halloween'
Short description:
Aeonium 'Halloween' is a brilliant hybrid of unusual colouring.
 \n
 \nThis fantastic plant is unusual due to the leaf markings and colours being so different from others, ranging from green, red and yellow. In strong light, the red line down the centre of each leaf is very distinctive. Additionally to it being unique, is the shape of the rosette. It may look like Aeonium 'Blushing Beauty' but it is a very common offsetter that keeps its branches close to create a very structural formation. Not only that, under strong light, the rosettes curl upwards and create a rose-bud shape. It is a truly extraordinary plant.
 \n
 \nThis plant deserves its own large pot to grow into and show off. It would fit perfectly on a porch or open windowsill.
Planting Location: Amber Zone
Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill, Part Shade
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Patio, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Echeveria 'Mr Grey'
Short description:
Echeveria 'Mr Grey' is a new introduction from our nursery that is believed to be a cross of Echeveria tolumanensis.
 \n
 \nThis plant features white, ghost-like colouring upon slender yet sharp looking leaves. The form is star-shaped and very neat. It will flower in the spring.
 \n
 \nPerfect as a standalone feature or in a planter with other succulents.

Name: Aeonium dodrentalis (cluster)
Short description:
The plant you receive is a cluster of the original plant. They are unusually clustering, despite being grown from seed.
 \n
 \nAeonium dodrentalis, commonly known as the Mountain Rose or Greenovia dodrentalis, has an attractive cupped rosette and compact stemless growth form.
 \n
 \nCan be grown as a potted succulent on a bright windowsill, makes a beautiful house plant. Little or no water all summer, this succulent grows during Autumn, winter and spring, water when compost dries during these seasons.
Light Aspect: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Part Shade
Planting Location: Conservatory, Garden, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill

Name: Pachyphytum 'Twilight'
Short description:
Pachyphytum 'Twilight' is a hybrid produced in 2015 by Surreal Succulents.
 \n
 \nThis plant consists of stunning dusk like colouring throughout the leaves but will turn candy-pink under high light levels. The leaves are the Pachyphytum geometric shape and are what gives this plant the name it deserves. It is a tall-growing plant that offsets at the base, just like a trident. It will bloom in spring with large Pachyphytum flowers.
 \n
 \nA great addition to any collection. Perfect in a pot on it's own or planted with other rares.

Mature Size: Bright Windowsill, Full Sun, Full Sun Windowsill
Growth Form: Conservatory, Garden, Indoor, Patio, Pot, Rockery, Wall, Windowsill
